On December 15, 1913, Diry, a middleweight, was knocked out by George Ashe in the third round of a contest at the National Sporting Club, in Brooklyn, New York. Diry was from Ireland, where his name was spelled "Deery." Although he had won a fight in November, this was his second loss in a row, and he would endure three more knockouts in 1914 before he hung up his gloves for good. Diry's boxing record: boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=73885&cat=boxer New York Times story, December 16, 1913 (NYT says he was a German, and had won several fights, but the record contradicts that statement): query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9807E...

From a more elaborate biography: Later called the "Big Groundhog" because of his birthday, Orval Overall was born on February 2, 1881, in Farmersville, California, a small agricultural community just outside of Visalia. Located in the San Joaquin Valley, about equidistant from Los Angeles and San Francisco, Visalia was already a thriving community of more than 1,000 inhabitants. Orval's father, Daniel, was a well-to-do businessman who owned the Palace Hotel in addition to a citrus farm, and Orval enjoyed an upper-class upbringing. After pitching and playing first base at Visalia High School, the 19-year-old Overall enrolled at the University of California-Berkeley in the fall of 1900. He excelled in his studies of agricultural science and was elected president of the freshman class. Overall was a star in both football and baseball at Cal. On the gridiron he played guard, fullback, and punter on the varsity, serving as captain as a senior. In his junior and senior years he played integral roles in California's victories over archrival Stanford. In baseball Orval performed the majority of the mound work as a freshman, pitching well but suffering from occasional mental lapses. Perhaps an early indicator of the arm troubles that would plague him in later years, he missed time from pitching due to a sore arm in both his sophomore and junior seasons. During those times Overall played left field, first base, and sometimes even catcher, though he inevitably returned to pitching as the seasons wore on and his arm rounded into shape. In his junior year he entertained an offer to play baseball for a living with the San Francisco club of the Pacific Coast League, but he decided to continue his education instead.

The title "Lord Weardale" puts the photograph at 1907 or later when his Lordship was elevated to the House of Lords.

According to the Wikipedia article captainslack linked to: "A prominent opponent of war - including the Boer War - he was president of the sixth National Peace Conference in Leicester in 1910, led the British group in the Inter-Parliamentary Union, and became president of that organisation from 1912 to 1922. He was also president of the Save the Children Fund and a trustee of the National Portrait Gallery. With Lord Curzon, he became in 1912 joint president of the National League for Opposing Woman Suffrage" The meeting with Andrew Carnegie was probably to do with his Inter-Parliamentary Union activities, which would have appealed to Carnegie in relation to the Carnegie Endowment. Perhaps it would have been in May 1913, when Weardale led a group from Britain and its colonies to a meeting in New York planning for celebrations of 100 years of peace among English-speaking peoples. See, for example, an NYT article on May 6, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9404E7D91F3AE633A... PEACE ENVOYS BEGIN CELEBRATION PLANS; Delegates from England and British Colonies Officially Welcomed by Gaynor.

Clews, Henry, c.1836–1923, American financier, b. England. He emigrated to the United States c.1850 and joined an import business as a junior clerk. In 1859 he cofounded the banking firm that later became Livermore, Clews, and Company, the second largest marketer of federal bonds during the Civil War. His own firm, Clews and Company, was formed in 1877. Refusing public office, he nevertheless organized the “Committee of 70,” which deposed the Tweed Ring in New York City. He served as President Grant's economic consultant in Japan and wrote and lectured widely on diverse social, political, and economic issues. He wrote Fifty Years in Wall Street (1908). from InfoPlease www.infoplease.com/ce6/people/A0812559.html

Arthur Lawley, 6th Baron Wenlock, GCIE, KCMG (12 November 1860–14 June 1932) was Governor of Western Australia from 1901 to 1902. He also worked as lieutenant governor of Transvaal from 1902 to 1905. The Perth suburb of Mount Lawley is named after him. Lawley was a son of the 2nd Baron Wenlock (1818–1880) and he served with the 10th Hussars, rising to the rank of Captain. On 15 October 1885, he married Annie Cunard, a daughter of Sir Edward Cunard, 2nd Baronet and they had three children: Hon. Margaret Cecilia Lawley (d. 1969) Hon. Richard Edward Lawley (9 May 1887–4 September 1909), killed in India in a hunting accident. Hon. Ursula Mary Lawley (born 8 June 1888–16 October 1979) He succeeded as Baron Wenlock on the death of his elder brother, the 5th Baron, who died without male heirs (as did his other two elder brothers), on 14 June 1931. Lawley died exactly a year later in 1932 in Freiberg, Baden-Württemberg, Germany and as he also did not have any male heirs, his title became extinct. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Lawley
He was a delegate to the Anglo-American Peace Centenary planning meeting in May 1913. See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3277073448/ and NYT article cited there.

Harry Lane (August 28, 1855–May 23, 1917) was an American physician and politician in the state of Oregon. A native of the state, he worked as the head of the state insane asylum before entering local politics and served as mayor of Portland. A Democrat, he then served as United States Senator from 1913 until his death in 1917. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Lane

Grand Duchess Olga Alexandrovna of Russia (Russian: О́льга Алекса́ндровна Рома́нова; Olga Alexandrovna Romanova) (June 13 [O.S. June 1] 1882–November 24, 1960) was the last Grand Duchess of Imperial Russia under the reign of her elder brother, Czar Nicholas II. Her father was Alexander III of Russia; her mother was the daughter of Christian IX of Denmark, Maria Feodorovna, formerly titled Princess Dagmar of Denmark. Raised at the Gatchina Palace of St. Petersburg, Russia, the young Grand Duchess was closest to her brother, "Misha", Grand Duke Michael Alexandrovich. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Duchess_Olga_Alexandrovna_of_...

Also from the Wiki link  

After the downfall of the Romanovs, she, her mother, and other relatives, were imprisoned in the Crimea. During a political upheaval within the ad interim, revolutionary government, the remaining family escaped to Copenhagen, Denmark. Upon the death of her mother in 1928, the Grand Duchess and her second husband, Nikolai Kulikovsky, moved to a farm near Copenhagen. During the spring of 1948, the family emigrated to Canada settling on a dairy farm in rural Campbellville, Ontario. Some years later they moved to the town of Cooksville near Toronto.

This was taken sometime between the morning of April 29, 1913 and the afternoon of May 3, 1913. On April 29, 1913 Secretary of State William Jennings Bryan arrived in Sacramento at the bidding of President Wilson to plead against the passage of California's Alien Land Law of 1913. That morning at 11am he addressed secret meetings of the legislature with Governor Johnson, Lieutenant Governor Wallace and 120 members of the legislature, according to this New York Times article: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C04E3D9173FE633A... Governor Johnson "rallied the anti-Japanese lobby, however, and the bill passed. despite statements by both the President and the Secretary of State that this law offered insult to the Japanses people and their government." ( ref. books.google.com.au/books?id=PKL4DQ4XLtUC&pg=PA45&... ) According to this New York Times article, Bryan addressed a joint session of the California Legislature on the afternoon of May 3, 1913 prior to his departure for Washington: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0DEED9173FE633A... The text of Bryan's speech to the California legislature in 1913 is here: www.archive.org/stream/farewellremarks00bryarich and it is therefore likely that the two others in the photograph apart from Bryan and Johnson are Lieutenant Governor Wallace, and or Speaker Young, and/or State Senator Lee C. Gates. Of course, the papers of William Jennings Bryan are in the Library of Congress, so there's likely to be more about this occasion there: lcweb2.loc.gov/service/mss/eadxmlmss/eadpdfmss/2006/ms006... Here's an article from the New York Times of April 27, 1913 giving much of the background to Bryan's pending visit to California: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9C0DE...
The evidence regarding when the photo was made is also helpful.  We'll adjust the date in the description, as well.  Thanks!

Crowprince Rudolf was married to Princess Stephanie of Belgium. They had one daughter together. The marriage was a very unhappy one. He was a very depressed young man with a tendency to morbidity. He had a string of girlfriends, some of them prostitutes. According to one of them, a girl named Mizzi Caspar, he had asked her once if she would die with him. She turned him down, shocked and afterwards tended to think that he had made a joke. Apparently he had thoughts of suicide even years prior to his death. Freiin Mary Vetsera was barely 17 years old at the time of her death (Rudolf was 30). She was introduced to him by his cousin, Countess Larisch. Mary had been "starstruck" with the crown prince for a while. She did anything he asked her to. Even to die with him ... Rudolf took Mary to his hunting castle Mayerling, where their bodies were found behind a locked door on January 30th 1889, both with a bullet to their heads. Conspiracy theories abound about it being a murder that had been covered up. I tend to think it had been suicide. Rudolf never got along with his father, the emperor Franz Josef and was even said to have been offered the crown of Hungary, should that country try to ceceed from Austria-Hungary. That would have been high treason and even though the relationship was completely deteriorated, Rudolf apparently had huge qualms over it. That and the fact that he was depressed for years must have triggered his escape from life. At least that's what I think ...

Charles Seymour Whitman (1868-1947) served as Republican Governor of New York from January 1915 to December 1918. He was also a delegate to Republican National Convention from New York in 1916. Whitman graduated from Williams College, class of 1890. Prior to his election as governor, he served as a New York City municipal judge and as Manhattan District Attorney. As District Attorney, he gained national fame in prosecuting New York City Police Lt. Charles Becker for the July 16, 1912 murder of Times Square gambling house operator Herman Rosenthal in front of West 43rd Street's Hotel Metropole (owned by Lower East Side Tammany Hall leader "Big Tim" Sullivan). Later, as Governor, Whitman signed Becker's death warrant and presided over his electrocution. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_S._Whitman "Whitman May Lose More Witnesses. District Attorney Finds That Three Are Being Intimidated and Are Wavering." Source: New York Times; September 7, 1912 Weblink: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=980CE5D81630E233A... "District Attorney Whitman Following Trail Leading to Captains and Detectives. With Grand Juries here and in Lakewood, N.J., grinding out indictments against men who have been engaged in the business of stealing and selling automobiles, the situation here took a turn yesterday where it became probable that police officials, including half a dozen precinct Captains, would become involved." Mrs. Tinnin is mentioned on page 105 of "The History of Woman Suffrage" (free here at Google Books.) She is cited as the first chairman of the Equal Franchise League, founded in 1914 as The Woman Suffrage Council. There are aslo a few Internet references to her as co-author of a religious play called "One Night in Bethlehem" published in 1925. More interesting to fans of the Bain Collection, Glenna Tinnin was, according to an article in a short-lived magazine called "National Waterways" (free here from Google Books,) the "...originator and designer of the Pageant-Procession...." which took place in Washington D.C. the day before Woodrow Wilson's inauguration in 1913 (article begins on page 210.) The Suffrage Pageant is the subject of several Bain photos, as is the parade. The article mentions several other women involved in the Pageant who are also subjects of various Bain photos, including our old friends Inez Milholland, Florence Noyes, Hedwig Reicher, and Mrs. Owens and Mrs. Moore. Small photos of various Pageant participants in costume accompany the article. I suspect that many of those photos are lurking in the Bain Collection, and might appear here in the LOC photostream someday.

Tarnation. I just referenced your Wikipedia article in another picture without knowing how fresh the info was. I did add a quote that google kept popping up in part or whole but do not have any further info.

I didn't even notice the identification conflict between the photo here and the same one in the National Waterways article. Mrs. Tinnin and Miss Wilson were the same age, so we wouldn't be able to tell them apart that way (there's a brief biographical entry for Flora Wilson on page 891 of "Woman's Who's who of America" published in 1914- also free at Google Books.) In the photo of Mrs. Tinnin on page 210 of the National Waterways book she's wearing a hat, and I'm unable to determine if she's the same woman in costume as Justice in the page 211 photo (and here.) However, the Justice photo and the sitting portrait do look like the same person, so if the Bain collection mislabeled one, it must have mislabeled both. Unfortunately, I can't find any other photos identified as Flora Wilson anywhere on the Internet for a comparison, nor can I find any photos identified as Mrs. Tinnin, other than the two in the Bain Collection and the one at the top of the National Waterways article. Another puzzle to be solved.

I think this is, in fact, Mrs. Tinnin (not Miss Wilson). In looking through Prints and Photographs Division photographs that are not digitized, I was able to find another portrait of Mrs. Tinnin--same features (though the person who had recorded the copyright deposit photograph in 1913 wrote the name as "Tinnan, Mrs. Glenda S."!). I also found a photograph of Flora Wilson in Prints and Photographs Division files, and another portrait of her is featured in the Washington Post (March 5, 1909, p. 5). Miss Wilson had a somewhat rounder face, less deep-set eyes, and differently shaped eyebrows. Which is not to say that the labeling on the suffrage parade/pageant photos is always accurate. See the title and notes for this photo from the 1913 pageant regarding the identity of the symbol and the individual playing her: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ppmsc.00032 The 1913 suffrage parade was the subject of an essay featured on the Library of Congress Web site as part of "American Women: A Gateway to Library of Congress Resources for the Study of Women's History and Culture in the United States". The essay highlights multiple Library of Congress collection materials that shed light on the parade and the planning that preceded it: memory.loc.gov/ammem/awhhtml/aw01e/aw01e.html It's also interesting to note that Mrs. Tinnin apparently continued to compose pageants and plays into the 1920s--see this play notice from the University of Iowa's Redpath Chautauqua Collection: hdl.loc.gov/loc.award/iauchau./ogle/2 Thanks, all, for turning up connections to other photos and sources on the Web!

"Word was received here last night of the death yesterday of Mrs. Glenna Smith Tinnin at a sanitarium in Chestnut Hill, Mass. She formerly lived at the Hotel Wellington, this city, and in Washington, D. C. Mrs. Tinnin was an organizer of the National Junior Theatre which gave performances at the Alvin Theatre here in 1931, and earlier, in Philadelphia, Boston, and Brooklyn. She directed the woman suffrage pageant in Washington in 1913."

From Wikipedia.  Sounds like an interesting guy.  

Joseph Hertz was born in Rebrin, Hungary (now Slovakia), and emigrated to New York City in 1884. He was educated at New York City College (BA), Columbia University (PhD) and the Jewish Theological Seminary of America (Rabbi, 1894, the Seminary's first graduate). His first Ministerial post was at Syracuse, New York.

In 1898, he moved to South Africa (Transvaal), to the Witwatersrand Old Hebrew Congregation, Johannesburg. He stayed there until 1911, despite attempts by President Paul Kruger in 1899 to expel him for his pro-British sympathies and for advocating the removal of religious disabilities of Jews and Catholics in South Africa. He was also Professor of Philosophy at Transvaal University College (later known as the University of the Witwatersrand), 1906-8. In 1911, he returned to New York to the Orach Chayim Congregation.

==Chief Rabbi==In 1913, Rabbi Hertz was appointed Chief Rabbi of the United Hebrew Congregations of the British Empire; his rival candidates had included Rabbi Moses Hyamson and Rabbi Bernard Drachman. Rabbi Hertz held the post until his death. His period in office was marked by many arguments with a wide variety of people, mainly within the Jewish community; the Dictionary of National Biography describes him as a "combative Conservative". It was said of him that he was in favour of resolving disagreements by calm discussion - when all other methods had failed.

This is not Belem prison. Belem prison was built in Mexico City in the 17th century as a convent and served long as an asylum and prison (The Story of Mexico, 1914, NYTimes). In the 1913 book Mexico, The Land of Unrest, it was portrayed as a vile, filthy prison easily ten times over capacity, and housing political prisoners as well as murderers. In February of 1913, the long-running revolution in Mexico spilled into the capital. Amid the conflict, Belem prison was shelled and five to six thousand convicts ran free. A photo in the Bain collection shows the walls fallen and a large hole can be seen in the main buildings. In a photo on page 14 of The Land of Unrest, government troops shoot from behind the collapsed wall. So what building is this? Written on the image is certainly "Belem prison Mexico" and "Palacio penal de Belem". But the high resolution TIFF from LC’s site shows text chiseled across the front of the building: "Palacio de Justicia del Ramo Penal". This is the Mexican Court of Justice. I can’t determine where this was in Mexico City or whether it still exists. After the 1917 constitution, the highest court was replaced with Suprema Corte de Justicia de la Nación, whose new home was completed in 1929. It is still in use, Flickr has photos with riot police and reflected in a window. Why was the Court of Justice newsworthy? On July 15, 1914 Francisco Carvajal became President of Mexico. A shot-in-the-dark guess is that the photo ran because he had been president of the Court of Justice. The Library of Congress has an unscanned photo with Carvajal and a peace commission in 1911. Belem made it into the Washington Post and New York Times constantly in the 1910s. Beyond simple criminals, any revolutionary, dignitary, capitalist, or journalist could find themselves jailed and perhaps put to death at a moment’s notice. The slow smoldering revolution probably put the Court of Justice in US newspapers as well. President Victoriano Huerta had lost his final battle in Guadalahara to constitutionalist revolutionaries. In early July 1914 Venustiano Carranza and his forces marched on Mexico City, led by Pancho Villa, Emiliano Zapata, and Alvaro Obregon. Huerta resigned as president and fled Mexico. Carvajal was sworn in as his replacement, and served for a solid month until August 15, 1914, when he turned the government over to Carranza peacefully. A large number of articles ran about Francisco Carvajal [I had spelled this incorrectly as Carbajal, perhaps I picked that up from period US newspapers?] in the Washington Post and New York Times from July 12, 1914, until he departed on August 20 for America to hopefully return to his career as a lawyer. In particular, July 12-19 has many biographical pieces and a couple of photographs. I found a number of interesting false positives while looking for a Belem prison of this design. In the 1910s, criminals with long sentences were sent to the federal penitentiary, called Palacio de Lecumberri. It was the other, better run prison in Mexico City. It was closed in 1976 and since 1994 the building has housed the Archivo General de la Nación (National Archives). There is an older supreme court building which houses the court library in Mexico City. In Belem, the capital of the state of Para, Brazil, a former prison was converted into the Museu do Estado do Pará (State Museum of Para). Also in Belem, Brazil is Casa das Onze Janelas, which now is home to a contemporary art museum and a restaurant Boteco das Onze Janelas. It was a mansion, but a couple of sites erroneously peg it as the town’s first prison.
This was the High Court Building, next to Belen Jail in Mexico City

I've been researching this building a bit more.

It was inaugurated on May 6, 1900, with President Diaz in attendance.  It held criminal courts (juzgados de lo criminal y correccionales) for Belem Prison.  It was built on the edge of the Belem Prison site - hence the original photo title - and was referred to as an annex.

I'm not sure how long it lasted.  It was surely damaged in the 1913 revolution.  In 1933 the entire prison was replaced with Revolution Elementary School, as @ciriaco mentioned.  It must have been very symbolic, because Belem had served as a girls school before being converted to a prison in the mid 1800s.

Now a days here is located Centro Escolar Revolución.  The block is surrounded by Arcos de
Belen (north), Dr. Río de la Loza (south); General G. Hernández (east) and Balderas (west). Colonia Doctores, Deletgación Cuauhtemoc. In this picture is shown north-west corner of Arcos de Belén (left-to-right) and Balderas (foreground-to-background), where Metro Balderas Norte is found. The camera is facing southwards,  Therefore by shadows casting you can say the picture was taken in the morning by 9 am.
You may found this information if you go to Google Maps.

This is the corner of Lafayette Street and White Street in New York City. I can tell because building on the far right is the Engine Company 31 Firehouse (Napoleon Le Brun & Sons, 1895). I have a current photo of it; it looks nearly the same except for some roofing detail, but a photo of the same corner from 1907 (scroll all the way down) shows the detailing intact. Another bit of evidence: the street address for the firehouse is 87-91 Lafayette Street, while the signage on the corner building shows the number "84" (backwards), which is presumably part of its street address. Additionally, according to Google Maps, the tall building in the middle with the arched windows at the top is still standing--it's at Lafayette and Walker, a block away. I'm going to guess that Hartigan was rushing over to the New York State Supreme Court building (as per Mr. Angstrom above) a few blocks down south.

Viola Dana
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to: navigation, search
Viola Dana, 1922

Viola Dana, sometimes credited as Viola Flugrath, (June 26, 1897 in Brooklyn, New York – July 3, 1987 in Woodland Hills, California) was an American film actress who was successful during the era of silent movies.

[edit] Career

Born Virginia Flugrath, Dana was a child star, appearing on the stage at the age of three. She read Shakespeare and particularly identified with the teenage Juliet. She enjoyed a long run at the Hudson Theater in New York City. A particular favorite of audiences was her performance in David Belasco's Poor Little Rich Girl, when she was 16. She went into vaudeville with Dustin Farnum in The Little Rebel and played a bit part in The Model by Augustus Thomas.

Dana entered films in 1910. Her first motion picture was made at a former Manhattan (New York) riding academy on West 61st Street. The stalls had been transformed to dressing rooms. Dana became a star with the Edison Company, working at their studio in the Bronx. She fell in love with Edison director John Hancock Collins (1889 - 1918) and they married in 1915. Dana's success in Collins's Edison features such as Children of Eve (1915) and The Cossack Whip (1916) encouraged producer B. A. Rolfe to offer the couple lucrative contracts with his company, Rolfe Photoplays, which released through Metro Pictures Corporation. Dana and Collins accepted Rolfe's offer in 1916 and made several important films for Rolfe/Metro, notably The Girl Without A Soul and Blue Jeans (both 1917). Rolfe closed his New York-area studio down in the face of the 1918 influenza epidemic and sent most of his personnel to California. Dana left before Collins, who was finishing work at the studio; however, Collins contracted influenza which rapidly turned into pneumonia and died in a New York hotel room on October 23, 1918.

Dana remained in California acting for Metro. In 1920 she became engaged to Ormer Locklear, a daring aviator and military veteran. Locklear died when his plane crashed on August 2, 1920 during a nighttime film shooting. (Dana witnessed the crash. She would not fly again for 25 years.) Locklear was the prototype for the Robert Redford movie, The Great Waldo Pepper (1975), and Dana was an honored guest for the premiere of The Great Waldo Pepper.
1928

Dana continued to act throughout the 1920s, but her popularity gradually waned. One of her last important roles was in Frank Capra's first film for Columbia Pictures, That Certain Thing (1928). She retired from the screen in 1929. Her final screen credits are roles in Two Sisters (1929), One Splendid Hour (1929), and (with her sister Shirley Mason, nee Leonie Flugrath) The Show of Shows (1929). By the time she made her final film appearance, she had appeared in over 100 films. More than 50 years after her retirement from the screen she appeared in the documentary Hollywood (1980), discussing her career as a silent film star during the 1920s. Footage from the interview sessions was used in the 1987 documentary Buster Keaton: A Hard Act to Follow.

Viola Dana died in 1987 from heart failure, aged 90. She is interred at Hollywood Forever Cemetery under her original name of Virginia Flugrath.

Viola Dana has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for her contribution to motion pictures. It is located at 6541 Hollywood Boulevard.

[edit]
There are lots of great pictures of her here on the Silent Ladies and Gents website: Viola Dana Photo Gallery

According to this site, Chief Meyers' actual name was John Tortes Meyers. His nickname came from the fact that he was a Native American. He was in the Cahuilla tribe, and his mother was a big part of his life. He even altered his diploma from high school, because he didn't finish. He took classes at Dartmouth with the help of a tutor, but was caught for having a false diploma. Shortly after that, his baseball career began as a catcher. bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&pid=9594&...

Adolf Lewisohn was a New York investment broker and philanthropist who died in 1938. He was a large contributor to Columbia University among many other New York City beneficiaries.

We have to be careful there are two brothers: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonard_Lewisohn en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolph_Lewisohn I looked through the marriage records for Manhattan and added the spouses to their Wikipedia articles: Adolph married Emma Cohn on June 26, 1878 in Manhattan Leonard married Rosalie Jacobs (1847-1900) on June 29, 1870 in Manhattan Looks like I found one spouse dead in the year 1900, that explains why she wasn't mentioned in the obit. The woman doesn't look 60 years old so this may be the wife of one of the sons.

Mrs Adolph Lewisohn (the former Emma Cahn) died in 1916, "in her sixtieth year." See NYT on July 29, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9407E2D7173BE633A... The obituary mentions two sons: Sam A and Julius A and grandchildren. So this could be one of their wives.NYT searching finds that Mrs Samuel Lewisohn was very much a socialite, active in charities, and left art to museums. I also find mention of a Dr. and Mrs. Richard Lewison and a Mrs. Philip Lewisohn. So there are lots of possibilities.

Continuing the hunt. It is probably NOT Mrs. Samuel Adolph Lewisohn, since they were not married until 1918. See query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0CE6D81130E433A... But Mrs Philip Lewisohn was Cleopatra in a charity pageant on December 6, 1913 See NYT, December 7, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E0DE3DF1F3BE633A... According to NYT, November 18, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=940CE3DA113AE433A... She was the daughter of Randolph Guggenheimer. NYT, May 6, 1897 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B06E5DB143DE633A... reveals that her name was Adele, but I have been unable to find any pictures of her.

There were two noted Misters Fred Beach in New York during the 1910s. Frederick Converse Beach was the son of Alfred Ely Beach, developer of the pneumatic subway, a short section of which was built in the city in 1869. The Beach family was long associated with Scientific American Magazine, and Frederick was the magazine's editor, as well as Editor-in-Chief of the Encyclopedia Americana. I can't find anything about a Mrs. Frederick C. Beach on the Internet, though their son, Stanley Yale Beach, comes up in searches. There's a great deal of information about a Mrs. Frederick O. Beach, though. Her Fred Beach was, according to the New York Times article about their 1899 wedding, a "popular clubman" and was "associated in business with the Beckwith-Chandler Company." This Mrs. Beach, born Miss Camilla Moss, was the widow of Charles F. "Carley" Havemeyer, who died of a gunshot wound in 1898- an "accident" according to the coroner's inquest as reported in the Times article about the incident. Both of these articles suggest that the Havemeyer's marriage may have been somewhat troubled. Mrs. Frederick O. Beach was in the news again in 1912 and 1913. While the couple were vacationing in the resort town of Aiken, South Carolina, she was attacked in her yard, receiving a serious neck wound. Rumors circulated that it was her husband who had stabbed her. A few weeks later, Fred Beach was formally charged for the attack. His trial was not held until February, 1913, when The Times published this story about it. A few days later, The Times announced that Mr. Beach had been acquitted. I can find nothing about the couple after 1913. Presumably, they resumed their former placid life- or returned to their private hell, as the case may have been. One result from a Google search on their names is a brief mention of a Mr. and Mrs. Fred Beach attending a society wedding in 1930, but I don't know if it refers to the same couple.

Frederick Converse Beach (son of Alfred Ely Beach) was married to Margaret Allen Gilbert (1848-1932). Their son Stanley Yale Beach had a son named Frederick Converse Beach II who died in 1940. I believe Frederick Converse Beach II had a son, Frederick Converse Beach Jr. (who died at age 3) by his wife Sarah B (per FCB, Jr.'s gravestone). There is also a gravestone in Union Cemetery in Stratford, CT for a Matilda Florence Sparling who is listed as Frederick C Beach II's wife. This picture could potentially be any of these women (Margaret, Sarah, Matilda).

The Salt Lake Tribune reported on the Beach trial in 1913. Chronicling America has the images of the original newspaper account. Trial to Clear Beach Case Mystery I haven't read far enough ahead to see how the case came out, but apparently Mrs. Beach accused an unidentified "Negro" of the assault, but the State felt differently. The State accused Mr. Frederick O. Beach of assaulting his wife after following her to what he believed was a tryst with a neighbor.

Good observation dyzzilet!  What we have is a photograph taken 1-24-13 of an earlier photograph.  We'll need more information about the original image before we fix the source data.

Harry Angstrom is incorrect.  Austen and Neville Chamberlain were the sons (half-brothers) of Joseph Chamberlain a prominent politician in Victorian England.  Austen won the Nobel Prize and Neville was the Prime Minister associated with the Munich agreement.

Joseph Chamberlain (no relation)

Further thoughts.

According to Wikipedia, Austen Chamberlain died in 1937 at the age of 73.  He would therefore be 49 at the time this photograph was taken if the date given is correct (1913) - not too old to be the father of the young girl, but gives pause for thought.

The date is in the American style, rather than the English style (which would be 24-1-13) so either it is not a date or one could surmise it has been added by an American curator or it is a purely American photograph.

Tentative conclusion:  This Mrs Austen Chamberlain is not the wife of the British politician.

Possibly Peruvian aviator Jean Bielovucci who flew from Paris to Bordeaux in 1910 (NY Times article) in a biplane. Later (1914), he was the first person to fly across the Alps. Most references call him "Aviator Bielovucci" -- the later NY Times article gives his name as "Jean"

Looks like "Bielovucci" is another bungled spelling, but bungled by both Bain and the New York Times. On the Internet, the error seems confined primarily to English and French language web sites. Sites in Spanish almost all spell his surname Bielovucic (and call him Juan rather than Jean.) Though born in Peru, he was of Croatian and French ancestry, and appears to have spent much of his adult life in France. The English language web site Early Aviators gets his name right, though. Click on the thumbnail of the 1911 "Circuit Europeen" card on that page and then scroll down to see Bielovucic's plane of that time, with an inset of him wearing what might be the same checkered cap he sports in this Bain photo. The plane in the Bain photo appears to be more modern, though, and might be the monoplane in which he crossed the Alps in January, 1913. Caps apparently outlasted aircraft in those days.

From Wikipedia

The Armenian Genocide (Armenian:  Turkish: Ermeni Soykırımı), also known as the Armenian Holocaust, the Armenian Massacres and, by Armenians, the Great Calamity —refers to the deliberate and systematic destruction (genocide) of the Armenian population of the Ottoman Empire during and just after World War I. It was characterised by the use of massacres, and the use of deportations involving forced marches under conditions designed to lead to the death of the deportees, with the total number of Armenian deaths generally held to have been between one and one-and-a-half million.[1] Other ethnic groups were similarly attacked by the Empire during this period, including Assyrians, Greeks, and Kurdish people and some scholars consider the events to be part of the same policy of extermination.[2]

The Albanians had assisted the Young Turks of the Ottoman Empire because of a promise that Albania would have autonomy and relief from repressive Turkish taxation. About 8000 Albanians in Kosovo and the northern mountains rebelled in March (or early April) 1910. The uprising soon spread to Korçë to the southeast and into western Macedonia. The Albanian leaders met in Montenegro, adopted a memorandum demanding self-government for Albania, and sent it to the Turkish government, which rejected it. A large Turkish army brutally crushed the uprising in June 1910. Albanian organizations were outlawed, entire regions were disarmed, and Albanian schools and publications were closed down.

Columbia University's Low Memorial Library was designed by architect Charles Follen McKim of McKim, Mead, and White, the firm that created the original master plan for the University's Morningside Heights campus. Internet sources differ on the date of construction. Columbia itself says it was completed in 1897. But then Columbia is also one of several Internet sources saying that the dome is built of granite, yet this 2003 article from Architectural Record reveals that it is actually built mostly of brick, and faced with limestone panels. Oh, Internets!

This is such an incredible structure.  When I went to the campus, I loved all of the architecture at Columbia University, but I was especially fond of the Low Memorial Library.  The Low family spent over $1 million in the late 1890's in order to finance the building, which is now the most popular and prominent building on campus.  This building is beautifully designed with massive columns and perfect symmetry.  Furthermore, this library is still used today as the administrative center by the university.  It is hard to believe that it was built over a century ago, and it is still as magnificent today as it was then!

I recently visited the campus this summer in the beginning of June.  Talk about amazing!  The architecture of the entire campus is awesome but the most memorable of all of the buildings was definitely the Low Memorial Library.  I was quite impressed with the fact that it is still in such great shape.  When looking at brochures of Columbia University, the Low Memorial Library was always pictured with students sitting on the steps and hanging out.  I knew that it was a popular place for students to lounge around but when I was actually there sitting on the steps, I quickly realized why it was such a great place to just sit and relax.
Current picture: www.ronsaari.com/stockImages/nyc/columbiaUniversityLowMem...

From Wikipedia

Myron Timothy Herrick (October 9, 1854 – March 31, 1929) was a Republican politician from Ohio. He served as the 42nd Governor of Ohio. He was born in Huntington, Lorain County, Ohio, the son of Timothy Robinson Herrick a local farmer. He married Carolyn Parmely.

Herrick served as the Governor of Ohio from 1904 to 1906. He subsequently served as United States Ambassador to France from 1912 to 1914 and again from 1921 to 1929, when he died from a heart attack while in office. Herrick was an unsuccessful candidate for the U.S. Senate in 1916 against Atlee Pomerene.

In Greek mythology, Iolaus (in Greek, Ἰόλαος) was a Theban divine hero, son of Iphicles, brother of Heracles and Automedusa.

He was famed for being Heracles' nephew and for helping with for some of his Labors. Through his daughter Leipephilene he was considered to have fathered the mythic and historic line of the kings of Corinth, ending with Telestes.

A species of butterfly has been named after him.

Sophie Braslau (1892-1935) was a contralto prominent in United States opera, starting with her debut in New York City's Metropolitan Opera in 1913 when she was just 21 years of age. [1] In her obituary The New York Times wrote, "The singer considered as her greatest triumph an experience during a rehearsal for a concert at Richmond, Va., where she had been sent to substitute for Mme. Louise Homer. After an introduction to the musicians in the empty auditorium, she sang an aria for rehearsal."
"I finished and there came a dead silence," she recalled later, "quickly followed by the strangest sound I had ever heard.  The musicians tapped their music stands with their bows or clapped their hands." In a few seconds it seemed as if pandemonium had let loose, and how happy I was! It was really the finest moment of my life. My mother was there, and it seemed to me that this was her triumph, for the evening concert was a great success and this was the first big joy she had experienced after her many years of devoted supervision."
(Many photographs of Mme. Homer can be seen in the LOC Bain Collection here.) There are currently nine photographs of Sophie Braslau in the LOC Bain Collection from c.1910-1915 here.)

She became Mrs. Thomas L. Chadbourne NYT query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A07E0DF153CE533A... SOCIAL NOTES; New York. January 10, 1921, Monday The wedding of Miss Marjorie A. Curtis, daughter of Mrs. H. Holbrook Curtis, and Thomas L. Chadbourne will take place on Saturday, Jan. 15, at the home of the bride's mother, 500 Madison Avenue, with none but relatives present.

Milton E. Ailes, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.
Milton E. Ailes -- A chapter in the book "130 Pen Pictures of Live Men" By Orlando Oscar Stealey, 1910, via Google Books

It seems that Ailes resigned from the Treasury in 1903 -- see NYT from March 29, 1903 at query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9804E4DA1E30E733A... -- he then joined Riggs Bank as Vice-President, eventually becoming President of the bank in 1921. He died suddenly in 1925. In the 1914-1915 period there was a dispute between Riggs and the Treasury, also reported in the NYT, e.g., in query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E00E2DE153EE033A...

L’ENGLE, Claude, a Representative from Florida; born in Jacksonville, Fla., October 19, 1868; attended the public schools and the Duval High School; engaged in mercantile pursuits; became editor and publisher of Dixie, a weekly newspaper; elected as a Democrat to the Sixty-third Congress (March 4, 1913-March 3, 1915); unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1914 to the Sixty-fourth Congress; again engaged in journalism; died in Jacksonville, Duval County, Fla., November 6, 1919; interment in Evergreen Cemetery. from: bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=L000548 from Wikipedia: Madeleine L'Engle Camp was born in New York City, and named after her great-grandmother, Madeleine L'Engle , otherwise known as Mado.[2] Her mother, a pianist, was also named Madeleine. Her father, Charles Wadsworth Camp, was a writer, a critic, and a foreign correspondent whose lungs were damaged by exposure to mustard gas during World War I. (In a 2004 New Yorker profile of the writer, relatives of L'Engle disputed the mustard gas story, claiming instead that Camp's illness was caused by alcoholism.)

Hyde inherited the world's biggest life insurance company, but lost control of it as the result of a public investigation in 1905. Hyde then left the country, so when these photographs were made, in 1913, he was living in exile in Paris. 

Here is some biographical info, from an online description of James Hazen Hyde's papers in the collections of the New York Historical Society (the New York Public Library also has a collection of his papers):

"James Hazen Hyde (1876-1959) was a businessman, francophile, and expatriate. He graduated from Harvard in 1898. In 1899 he was left in charge of his father's (Henry Baldwin Hyde, 1834-1899) life insurance company, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. In 1905 Hyde lost control of the company in a publicity scandal that resulted in an investigation of the insurance industry by the New York State. In late December 1905 Hyde sailed for Paris, where he lived until the Nazi occupation. 

"Collection consists of correspondence, diaries, scrapbooks and other papers from 1891-1941 pertaining to his interest in Franco-American relations, e.g., Fédération de l'Alliance, Cercle Français de l'Université Harvard, American Field Service Fellowships, American lecture tours by French professors, his work in the American Red Cross in France during World War I, his social life, anecdotes and comments about prominent persons, especially in French government, military, and educational circles, personal affairs, etc."

Another Bain/LOC photo of Hyde in his library:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3047668569/in/photostream/]

I believe the abbreviation is Linc. Daniels. As in Lincoln Daniels.

Thanks!  You are correct that the abbreviation (a bit illegible in the negative) is "Linc." and it stands for "Lincoln."  I hunted in one of the Prints and Photographs Division's photo files and found a photographic print that corresponds to this image.  The Bain News Service caption on the back, dated Jan. 27, 1913, says, "Linc. Daniels has been visiting New York and he has regretted all through his stay that he did not bring his compass with him. Linc. says it is much easier to find your way through the woods near Sebago Lake in Maine, where he lives, than through the streets of New York...Linc. is 82 years old and the oldest guide in all Maine."

We'll flesh out the title and date in our source description and reload it to Flickr.

Linc Daniels was one of the most successful Sebago Lake guides, and at a time when big landlock salmon were plentiful. It's quite likely that Linc used fishing rods made by his brother, James B. Daniels of Auburn (ME).

Prince Ernst ist Prince Ernst August from Hanover de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_August_(Braunschweig-L%c3%bcn... he was the youngest son of the last crown price of the kingdom of Hanover Ernst August, duke of Cumberland and princess Thyra of denmark, daugghter of king Christians IX.of Dänemark. He was born in 1887.

Ernst Augusts' father had rights to the throne of the Dukedom of Braunschweig. When he and Viktoria Luise married, his father gave up those rights in favor of his son. And so, in 1913, Ernst August and Viktoria became the reigning Duke and Duchess of Braunschweig and Lüneburg. (That used to be part of the kingdom of Hannover, which at that time was a prussian province. That stayed that way, only Braunschweig and Lüneburg became its own little Duchy.) Ernst August and Viktoria Luise only reigned until 1918. Did you know that through his mother Ernst August was closely related to the english and russian thrones? His mothers' sister Alexandra was Queen of England and his other aunt Dagmar was Empress of Russia. She took the name Maria Fjodorowna and was the mother of the last tsar Nicolaus II.

It is likely Cipriano Castro, ex-president of Venezuela, who is mentioned in the article swanq found about Victor Castro. Searching the Prints & Photographs Online Catalog ("PPOC") ( www.loc.gov/rr/print/catalog.html ), I found another image of Castro in New York--a photo the Library of Congress acquired after it was deposited for copyright in Feb. 1913 (see: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3a48090 ). It looks to be the same man, and there he is identified as Cipriano, the ex-president. An additional image that shows his face better is: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3c00798 . He is also featured in a couple of cartoons in PPOC. Cipriano Castro apparently arrived in New York early in 1913 (see: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9D03E... ). We'll add some identifying information to both this image and a related image, flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3047667193/ Thanks for getting the identification ball rolling!

Former dictator of Venezuela (1899-1908), the deposed tyrant, General Cipriano Castro, attempted a U. S. visit in January, 1913, but was detained at Ellis Island in quarantine. That is when this photo and its companion were taken, by the Bain News Agency. Apparently he was let in, however, and as a private citizen attended the inauguration of U. S. President Woodrow Wilson in Washington, D.C., on March 4, 1913. In 1916, Castro was again detained at Ellis Island when he attempted to land at New York while en route from Trinidad to Porto {Puerto} Rico. Story in New York Times, July 17, 1916: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C03E3D9173BE6...

The former Frances Gibson, an actress and singer who left her first husband, attorney Walter Bowne, to "run off" with Maj. Jordan Lawrence Mott III (1881-1931), who finally became her second husband in 1928, when he was free to marry again. www.northumpqua.org/river/mott.html

NYT article of February 27, 1914, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F07E6DE163AE633A... indicates that the "running off" was early in 1912, to the Far East. By the date of the article, Bowne had divorced Frances, but Mott was still married. It seems likely that the picture was taken before she ran off with Mott. Interestingly, at roughly the same time, late February, 1914, was the day Bowne remarried. See query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F05E4DE163AE633A... The NYT has her maiden name as Hewitt in some cases and Hewett in others, but it was definitely Hewett in Time Magazine, when her eventual marriage to Mott was reported. In 1912, Le Prieur watched as Maurice Fernez remained underwater through the aid of a surface pump. Inspired by Fernez’s display, Le Prieur wanted to find a way to do the same thing underwater. Fourteen years later, the two men teamed up and produced the lightweight breathing apparatus that Jacques Cousteau would later refine and popularize.

It seems surprising to me that suffragettes would resort to arson. I wondered if the fire was really caused by reactionaries trying to make them look bad but apparently not. Were suffragettes more militant than I realized or were they more militant in Great Britain than the US? Here are a couple short articles in the New York Times dated March 11, 1913 which mention the fire. [1],[2] The date on this photo is currently set to 'some time in 1910. It should probably be set to March 11, 1913, or at least 'some time in 1913'.

Let’s hear it for Mrs. Pankhurst! SUFFRAGETTES TRY TO REACH THE KING 3/10/1910 New York Times … "Mrs. Pankhurst read the petition which it had been desired to present to the King. It declared that the militant movement for votes for women was endangering all forms of public and private property and had brought the administration and the law in to contempt." “All thinking persons”, it went on, “were eagerly and impatiently waiting to see whether the speech from the throne would contain a promise of legislation by which the suffragists’ violence and its consequences could be brought to append. “Votes for women” it continued, “Is the only cure for militancy. The revolting and futile policy of releasing hunger-strikers and re-arresting them, and again releasing them and re-arresting them, would simply bring discredit upon the Ministers responsible for it. Such treatment will never break the spirit of the women, though it will very likely bring about a tragedy, for although the women cannot be defeated they can be killed by persecution. If law and order are to be re-established in this realm, women must have votes.”

The station was burnt down by Agnes Olive Beamish (aka Phyllis Brady) and her fellow suffragette friend Elsie Duvall (aka Millicent Dean). Both spent many years in prison for other acts of arson, mainly for setting fire the a house belonging to Lady White. Elsie managed to avoid going to prison for this by fleeing to France. Olive (she preferred to be known by her middle name) was not so lucky. I knew Olive in her later years, and you would never have guessed her past life and experiences by looking at the old lady! She died in 1978. Elsie died in 1919.

I agree that it is probably a replica. The helmet is an odd shape at the base. The chest piece is missing some of the parts that Ned Kelly built into his original. This includes holes for shoulder straps and a curved edge of the lower edge from by the original shape of the mouldboard or plough. The iron skirt is attached by two, not one strap. In addition, the replica seems to have a extra back skirt panel. The shoulder pads were designed to protect the upper arm and from what I can see they were not bolted on to protect the top of the shoulder. My guess is that somebody had some fun reconstructing this from a drawing in a newspaper. It would be interesting to see how accurate the newspaper drawings were and if any depicts these same errors. If anybody is curious, there is also a good video here that details a suit of armor used by these bush-rangers. www.slv.vic.gov.au/collections/treasures/kelly_armour/kel...

Satan's lil' workshop.

These don't seem to be torture devices but restraining devices. Most of them are clearly prisoner irons. The spiky one in the center would be attached to the end of a long pole and thrust against an escaping person's neck, trapping them between the arms which would spread to allow the person's neck in and then swing shut. Once the escapee's neck was trapped between the spiked ring, they had incentive to stop running. This was used by police officers on the mainland as well for centuries, although originally they were made of flexible wood or metal and without spikes.

When I think of torture device, I think of something that was designed solely for the purpose of inflicting pain on people, whereas these devices are primarily for restraint.
Looks like my basement :)

It should be noted that the ship 'Success' never transported convicts and these devices were never in use on board this vessel. She was a stationary prison or "hulk" near Melbourne, Australia in the 1850s. She toured the world as an exhibition for 50 years and was an extraordinary example of early 19th century shipbuilding, having been constructed of native teak in Burma. My website has her complete history. Rich Norgard www.shipsuccess.com www.shipsuccess.blogspot.com

After doing some research, I believe this scene occurred December 31, 1912 in the afternoon.  On December 30th, 32 officials of the International Assocation of Bridge and Structural Iron Workers were sentenced to Federal prison by Judge Anderson for their part in the "dynamite conspiracy".  

 Thirty-two "dynamiters" under arrest were transported from the Marion County Jail in Indianapolis by an equal number of deputies under Marshal Schmidt.  They marched south on Alabama Street to the Virginia Avenue viaduct where they boarded a special train.  A squad of Indianapolis Police was also on hand.  They were transported to Leavenworth Prison via St. Louis.  Source:  Indianapolis Star, December 31, 1912 and January 1, 1913.

According the the 1/1/1913 Washington Post (page 3 "Prison train on Way"), the train left Indianapolis and headed to the federal prison in Leavenworth, Kansas. This was a special prison train with two passenger coaches and one baggage car that departed at 12:10 in the afternoon. 33 convictec conspirators were transported at once. The train carried the nickname "dynamiters' special". It was boarded at a siding near the county jail. US Marshals and news reporters accompanied the prisoners. According to the 1/3/1913 Washington Post (p1 "Plotters in 'Pen'") the train was greeted by cheering crowds at every station, though the trip was supposed to be somewhat secret. Midnight was spent passing Jefferson County, Missouri, where the prisoners were allowed to drink coffee to celebrate the new year. Near Kansas City they passed a rail road bridge which the dynamiters had blown up as part of their conspiracy. Ironically, "almost the first question on entering the penetentiary was about the library" -- they blew up part of the Hawthorne Library in Indianapolis.

This is almost certainly the July 1913 excursion. The 1912 trip was intended to include a girl from each of Oregon's 36 counties; the latter trip included only Laura M. Dawson, Harney County, Ore.; Belle C. Nelson, Vernonia, Oregon; Mable Morrison, Colfax, Wash.; Sara Mosley, Bickleton, Wash.; May Springer, Walla Walla, Wash.; Ethel Hutchcroft, Yamhill, Ore.; Nett R. Drew, Klamath Falls, Ore.; Marvel Ramey, Nez Perce, Idaho; Mrs. G. L. Barkley, Ellensburg, Wash., and organizer Phil S. Bates, Portland. The 1913 party is recorded as having stayed at the Martha Washington Hotel: oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn96088246/1913-07-12/ed-1/se...
I found a citation that the 1912 party included 40 people, but haven't found a roster like that for 1913.
This Ethel Hutchcroft (1893-1966; Mrs. Ernest Groocock) of Yamhill County OR would have been 20 in 1913: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=90687842

Found this: WESTERN GIRLS WANT TO BORROW LIBERTY BELL New York's Horse Cars and Slit Skirts Set Their Tongues Wagging Fast New York Sun, 18 June 1913, p. 6 "Eight girls from Washington, Oregon, and Idaho arrived in New York yesterday on their way to Philadelphia, where they will try to borrow the Liberty Bell for the Panama Canal Exposition in San Francisco. They were not favorably impressed with New York. "'I had come to the biggest city in the country to see my first horse car,' said Miss Marvel Ramey of Nez Perce, Idaho, whose red cheeks and sturdy figure proclaimed her Western origin. 'I never saw such poor street car service anyway. And the way the men push! But when you look at the poor things and how pale and hollow eyed they are you know they need the seats worse than you do and you would be ashamed to take one. "'I didn't look at the women's faces on Fifth avenue. Their clothes were beautiful.' "'I thought they were dreadful,' said Mrs. G. L. Barkley, Superintendent of Schools in Kittias county, Washington, who is chaperoning the expedition. 'Why, I saw a woman as old as I am and I could see through the slit in her skirt.' "She added that girls who go West can find plenty of husbands. 'But,' she said, 'our young men are wise. They are more apt to ask whether a girl can make good bred than whether she can wear a slit skirt effectively.'"

"Mrs. G. L. Barkley" was Geneva Lincoln Barkley (1869-1932--the first name is sometimes spelled "Genevra"), Superintendent of Public Instruction for Kittitas County, Washington; married to Wooster Nathaniel Barkley (1870-1936); so she would have been 44 in 1913. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Barkle...; news.google.com/newspapers?id=-csrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cIQFA... (I notice the current city manager in Ellensburg is Ted Barkley, might be kin.)

The "Nett R. Drew" in Ben Truwe's roster must be Nett Drew Peterson (1884-1957), who was a school principal before she married. She would have been 29 in 1913. She married that same year, to Fred Peterson, who was a county school superintendent (like Mrs. Barkley) for decades. Here's Nett's gravesite, with her 1957 obituary: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=33201212

John Bernard "Hans" Lobert (October 18, 1881 - September 14, 1968) was an American infielder, coach, manager and scout in Major League Baseball. Lobert was born in Wilmington, Delaware. Like shortstop Honus Wagner, a teammate of Lobert's when he first came to the major leagues, the German-American Lobert earned the nickname "Hans" as a familiar form of Johannes, the German version of his given name, and was dubbed "Hans Number 2" by Honus Wagner. Lobert batted only .274, but he played 14 seasons (1903, 1905-17) with five National League clubs, including regular stints as a third baseman for the Cincinnati Reds (1906-10) and Philadelphia Phillies (1911-14). He also played with the Pittsburgh Pirates (1903), Chicago Cubs (1905) and New York Giants (1915-17). During his career, Lobert was known as one of the fastest, if not the fastest, players in the game. He once raced a racehorse around the bases before a game. After managing in the minor leagues during the 1920s and early 1930s, Lobert became a coach for the Phillies from 1934 through 1941. At 60, he became one of the oldest rookie managers in baseball history when he was appointed skipper of the 1942 Phils, in the midst of the longest streak of futility in their history. Under Lobert, the club "improved" by losing only 109 games (they had lost 111 under Doc Prothro in 1941). Counting two losses as an interim manager in 1938, Lobert's career managing record was 42-111 (.275). After his one season at the Phillies' helm, Lobert's career in uniform ended as a Cincinnati coach (1943-44). He than became a scout for the Giants of New York and San Francisco, serving until his death in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania at age 86. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Lobert

In the scene there is an architectural oddity; in the building directly to the left of and to the rear of the monument is an old building which by its alignment with one directly behind it appears to be "out of plumb" by a significant degree.  Any vertically plumb lines must line up as parallel lines visually and these do not.  It is possible that both buildings are "leaning" and the apparent amount is a cumulative effect.  The only other possible explanation is that the front planes of one or both of these two buildings are purposely built inclining but that does not seem to be the case. The nearest of those two buildings is composed of a columned front in tiered vertical groupings.

To the left in the photo the columned buildings facing the circle in a concave front are very impressive.  They remind one of some of the structures of ancient Rome.  But note too, that the nearest of that curved front is lacking a hand and safety rail which is apparently provided further in the distance.

I contacted the Indianapolis HIstorical Society about this photo.  They have the same photo in their collection as a negative.  No additional information about date beyond "1918" is listed for it.

Their researcher mentions that purportedly there were 65 parades in June alone in Indianapolis that year.  They believe that this photo is NOT Armistice Day because of the light clothing of the crowd, which doesn't match other photos of Armistice Day.

I wonder if it is possibly Americanization Day.  No one is wearing a uniform, but I don't know if that rules out a soldiers' farewell parade.

The building along the left of the photograph is the English Hotel.  It'd seem that this picture was taken from the east side of the second story of that building.

Dallas Love Field is a very convenient airport for the city of Dallas that has been around for a considerable amount of time.  This specific airport allows people to travel without having to drive all the way to the DFW airport, which is about 45 minutes away.  Dallas Love Field opened in 1917, (opened to the public in 1927) and it has been a successful airport with major airline carriers such as Southwest Airlines, Continental Airlines, and Delta Airlines.  However, throughout the years there have been a lot of legal issues and court battles that DFW Airport fought in order to keep Dallas Love Field from expanding.
The aircraft appear to be Standard J-1s. See www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=270

Sorry to have to put the entire poem here, but it is tricky to link to. The Honor Role By Chaplain W.A. Hopkins, U.S.N. 'Twas a clear September morning, Of the fifth, on Thursday morn; With the rainbow - sailor's warning - Arched across the radiant dawn; And our proud ship swiftly steaming To the throb of engines' pound, Seemed to chime in with our dreaming To the tune of "homeward bound." All the firemen fain would tarry On the boat deck in the sun, 'Ere they go below to carry Rest the mates whose work in done; But the hour is seven-fifty, All the "watches" change at eight, And we see them rise and swiftly Go below to meet their fate. For a submarine is lurking Listening for our engines' throb, Now the periscope is working As they plan their hellish job; Barks our forward gun a warning Answers back the telltale "wake", Death the U-boat now is scouring, With Mount Vernon as its stake. Comes the swift torpedo wining, Straight and sure has been their aim; As our huge transport is swinging For position in the game; Fair amidships strikes the warhead Just beneath the boiler room Squarely on our center bulkhead, Hurling firemen to their doom. Thirty thousand tons of metal Lifted, twisted, cracked and bent, Ten feet lower soon we settle As the water fills the rent, Dead three dozen loyal brothers, Shipmates true and heroes bold, Pride of sweethearts, wives, and mothers Now adorn the honor roll. 'Ere our ship has ceased to shiver Depth bombs roll from her stern, Salvos roar and engines quiver As the U-boats might we spurn Every man sticks by his station- "Stand by till death" is naval law- Traditions of our mighty nation Are kept without a flaw. Soon we circle wide the ocean Like a crippled bird in flight While destroyers spread commotion With the searching depth bombs might; Then to port our ship is headed, Listed now and wounded sore, Off across the war zone dreaded Back three hundred miles to shore. Sixteen hours of super-steaming On one half our boilers power, Bring us to a light house gleaming Traveling fourteen knots and hour; Through a mined and narrow channel, Dark, and swept by inbound tide, Water-logged and hard to handle, Glides our ship to berth inside. Letters, wireless, orders, cable Praise our Captain and his Crew For the work so brave and able Which has brought us safely through; But our hearts are bowed in sorrow, And the praise in tinged with pain As we view with deepening horror, Thirty six of our comrades slain. There's the price and theirs the glory, Ours the task to "carry-on", Theirs the right to history's story Ours to fight till war is won- Till the sacred right of freedom And the gleam of freedom's light Meets and beats the brutal demon Triumphant in the Right 'ore Might."

Bill Killefer

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

William Killefer (October 10, 1887 - July 3, 1960), nicknamed "Reindeer Bill", was an American catcher and manager in Major League Baseball who had a 12-year career for the St. Louis Browns, Philadelphia Phillies, and Chicago Cubs. He played for the 1915 Phillies team that lost to the Boston Red Sox in the World Series, and after the 1917 season, he was traded to the Cubs with Grover Cleveland Alexander for two players and $55,000 in cash. In 1918 he played in another World Series, losing again to the Red Sox. He retired from playing at age 33 in 1921, becoming the manager of the Cubs shortly after. He was fired after 75 games in 1923, and after five years away from managing, he was hired by the Browns in 1930, with little success, never finishing above fifth place. His managerial record was 524-622 (.457) in nine seasons.

He died in Elsmere, Delaware, at age 72.

June 1, 1912, Saturday The war of the waiters was waged furiously yesterday from early morning till night -- from breakfast time until the dinner hour -- and when the striking hotel workers gathered last evening to recount their victories at a mass meeting their leaders could report that seventeen hotels and restaurants had been wounded during the day. There seem to have been several people with the name Fuad Pasha or Fuad Pacha. [These transliterations appear to be interchangeable.] And it's hard to figure out which might be the same and which this might be. The NYT article cited above suggests that that Fuad Pacha was imprisoned for collaborating with the Young Turks. If so, he might have been free and active again by the period of the Bain collection, since Abdul Hamid II was deposed in 1909. Could this possibly be the same as en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuad_Pacha ? From Wikipedia, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuad_Pasha , Fuad Pasha (1815 – 1869) was a Turkish statesman known for his leadership during the Crimean War and in the Westernization movement within the Ottoman Empire. He gets lots of hits in the NYT, and has a name authority record at LoC as Mehmed Fuad Pasa but this photo seems unlikely to be him. books.google.com/books?id=t_uhI1J7AIgC&pg=PA153 identifies two Fuad Pashas, one a governor of Hijaz in 1909, and the other a "Tanzimat statesman." Dates in en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanzimat suggest it would be Fuad Pasha (1815–1869) who was the Tanzimat statesman. Perhaps this photo is of the other. Yet another Fuad Pasha (see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuad_I_of_Egypt) became Sultan of Egypt and Syria in 1917 and King of Egypt in 1922. He was born in 1868 and died in 1936. The only mentions of "Fuad Pasha" in the NYT in the 1910-1915 period identify a Field-Marshal Fuad Pasha, leading Turkish forces in 1912. There are no hits for "Fuad Pacha" in that period.

The whole family story is really interesting. Henry Sr. was a successful financier who founded an investment company. www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/USAclews.htm He wanted Henry Jr. to follow him into the business but Henry Jr. became an artist and moved to France. www.gis.net/~scatt/clews/clews_index.html and www.amb-cotedazur.com/index.php?option=com_content&vi.... He was married twice and bought a chateau near Cannes. www.chateau-lanapoule.com/index.html Henry III was Henry Jr.'s son by his first wife, Louise Morris Gebhard. Henry III turns up in the Google newspaper index for 1925 where he seems to avoid an engagement to a woman named Vera Latimer. Unfortunately all the articles are behind a paywall. Madeleine Talmage Force Astor Dick Fiermonte (1893-1940), wife of John Jacob Astor IV; they married in 1911, when she was 18 and he was 47. JJA IV died on the Titanic the next year; Madeleine was also on board, but survived: she was pregnant at the time, and gave birth to JJA VI soon after. In 1916, she remarried (a banker), giving up her right to any inheritance from JJA IV. She had two more sons and divorced her second husband in 1933. A few months later she married the third time, this time to a boxer, only to divorce in 1938. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madeleine_Astor

Cornell University crew on the Hudson River. Men's eight oarsmen boat. The photo is dated 1912. In the date range of the collection (1910-1915), Cornell won varsity 8 in 1910, 1911, and 1912. Not clear if this is training, or preparing for the annual championship at Poughkeepsie. In the background is the Poughkeepsie Railroad Bridge (which is planned to reopen by Oct 2009 as a pedestrian bridge). According to Bridging the Hudson, a rail signalman would stand on the bridge and use flags to show who was winning the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's annual championship on the Hudson. The race, the Poughkeepsie Regata, has recently been revived by the Hudson River Rowing Association. Framing the photo with this bridge in the background would give interested readers a clear sense of place.

"Bombardier" Billy Wells (1889-1967) was born William Thomas Wells in London, England. He began his professional boxing career in 1910, after serving four years with the Royal Artillery in India (where he was, indeed, a Bombardier.) He held the British Empire heavyweight boxing championship title from 1911 to 1919. He won 41 of his 52 bouts. Wells was also the second of the four athletes who, through the years, struck the enormous gong seen at the beginning of movies made by British producer J. Arthur Rank. BoxRec bout list. Presumably taken in New Mexico in the lead up to Jack Johnson's July 4, 1912 fight with Jim Flynn. Marty Cutler and "Professor" Burns were mentioned as sparring partners that accompanied Johnson from Chicago in a May 25, 1912 NY Times article ("Johnson Starts for Las Vegas"). The Library of Congress has two related photos, of Jim Flynn sparring and of Jim Flynn's training camp. (Note that this is not the Burns - Tommy Burns - that Johnson beat in his legendary July 4 1910 December 1908 fight. Tommy Burns was a sparring partner for Flynn, according to a May 1, 1912 NY Times article ("$1,100 for Johnson's Training").)

This photo is a promotion for the July 4, 1912 fight between Jim Flynn and Jack Johnson. Tommy Ryan, a retired middleweight champion, was Flynn's trainer until June 17, when he quit after an quarrel of unknown subject with promoter Jack Curley (NY Times June 18 1912, "Ryan Quits as Flynn's Trainer"). The Library of Congress also has a photo of Flynn at his training camp, and Johnson sparring.

"Assuming an Irish name was not unusual in that era of boxing; there were Jewish fighters with Irish names too; and Jim Flynn, the only man who ever knocked out Jack Dempsey, was actually named Andrea Chiariglione. One reason for the name changes is that there were not enough Irish fighters to satisfy the large number of Irish fans." -- Pete Hamill, "Why Sinatra Matters" (Boston: Little, Brown, 1998), p. 58.

Las Vegas, New Mexico (inscription on the photo makes this clear, but not the Flickr title). In 1912, Jim Flynn fought Jack Johnson in a July 4th match, scheduled to go 45 rounds for the world heavyweight championship. It was broken up after 9 rounds by state police because Flynn, bloody and beaten, had given up any real tactics and was simply trying to launch into Johnson with headbutts. Here's the round-by-round from the New York Times. Another New York Times article from just before the match writes it off as a gimmick match. Flynn was aging and was never a world-class boxer. Johnson was mentioned in the article as two years retired and fat, but he looks in good shape in contemporary photos, and continued fighting for more than fifteen years. "Flynn's Camp" should be regarded as the training camp for the fight, not an actual camp name. Flynn was a fireman in Pueblo, Co. A May 2, 1912 NYTimes article ("$1,100 for Johnson's Training") says that Flynn's camp would be in Montezuma, NM. Jack Curley was Jim's manager for the fight as well as the fight's promoter. Not sure on others in the photo. (by the way, Las Vegas, Nevada, our present-day boxing locus, was in 1912 a year-old city filled with dude ranches for guys wanting to get six weeks of residency for a legal divorce)

This photo is a set with two others: Johnson sparring and Flynn posing as if sparring. Inscription on the photo indicates which name goes to which man. From left to right in front: Al Williams, A. H. Balke, Jim Flynn, C. Colman, Jack Curley, Joe Flynn, C. O'Malley. In the back row, left to right, are M. M. Padget and H. Elfeld. Strangely, the man in between the two rows is not named. With leaves just sprouting from the tree, this looks like an early spring photo. The fight was discussed in papers from the end of 1911.

Noisette won first prize for "Limit, Bitches" at the April 19, 1914 French Bulldog Specialty Show in New York. In a New York Times article the next day ("Victory For Dr. De Luxe"), Noisette's owner is listed as John E. Haslam. Haslam had another Frenchie, Melisande, who took "reserve" for the "Winners, Bitches" in the same show. Many experts felt that Melisande was the strongest contender and deserved the award. John Haslam served as president of the French Bulldog Club of America.

Koji Yamada was a billiards expert from Japan. He played Willie Hoppe (LC Bain photo) several times for the 18.2 and 14.1 billiards title. In a 1914 match, Hoppe overcame a 210 point defecit to defeate Yamada. A Nov 3 1912 NY Times Article ("Jap Billiardist to Play for Title") has a short bio. Yamada had been living for two years in Berlin. At the time he was the shortest contender for the billiards title. He was ambidextrous and seldom used a bridge. He is described as "matter of fact", "prompt", and efficient. Included in a 1910's Brunswick ad for the Billiards Experts of the World.

Kid Williams (1893-1963) was born John Gutenko in Copenhagen, Denmark. His family immigrated to the United States in 1904, settling in Baltimore, Maryland. He began his professional career there in 1910, at the age of 16, with a fifth-round KO of Shep Farren. In 1914, he took the Bantamweight World Championship title from boxer Johnny Coulon, knocking him out in the third round of a scheduled twenty-round bout held at Vernon, California. He lost the title to Pete Herman in 1917. Williams' boxing career continued until 1929, finally totalling more than 200 bouts, of which he won 156. Kid Williams at the International Boxing Hall of Fame. Box Rec bout list.

Wladek Zbyszko (1891-1968) was a Polish professional wrestler: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wladek_Zbyszko His older brother Stanislaus Zbyszko (1879-1967) was also a professional wrestler: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanislaus_Zbyszko Zbyszko wasn't the family name, it was a nickname from childhood that they both used professionally.

I think this photo may depict Stanislaus, rather than Wladek. There's a photo of Stanislaus on this page at the Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame. He has that moustache. Maybe the clean-shaven Zybszko in this Bain photo, who I originally took to be Stanislaus, is actually Wladek. There are quite a few pictures of both brothers on the Internet, and they were remarkably similar, but most of the pictures identified as Stanislaus show a guy with a moustache, while those identified as Wladek show him without facial hair. Some undated photos of Wladek here. Two undated photos of Stanley (Stanislaus) here. Photo of an older Stanislaus, sans moustache, here. It's puzzling, anyway.

Heavyweight boxer Dan Daily was born in Williamsport, Pennsylvania, in 1887. His professional boxing career lasted from 1911 to 1922, though only three of his 28 bouts took place after 1914. At 6'6" (1.98 meters), he was one of the tallest boxers ever to enter the ring. BoxRec bout list.

George Chip (1888-1960) was born George Chipulonis, in Scranton, Pennsylvania. He held the world middleweight title from October 11, 1913, until April 7, 1914, having successfully defended it five times in six months. His career lasted from 1909 to 1922, with 71 wins in a total of 164 bouts. BoxRec bout list.

A search for 'Lefty Flynn' in the NYT archive yields some interesting tidbits. Maurice Bennett Flynn, a Yale football player (fullback in the 1912 team) married a chorus girl in January 1913, and separated a few days later. He was divorced by her 6 months later. However, it appears that the damage to his Yale career was done; he was not allowed to return after his marriage to the chorus girl. So presumably this photo was taken in late 1912, since his debut was in October 1912. In the 1920s he became an actor in silent movies. See www.imdb.com/name/nm0283555/ He died in 1959 -- after several more marriages.

I can't find any Clyde Morgan who played professional baseball during the 1910s, so that's Bain naming error. Clyde Milan (1887-1953) was born Jesse Clyde Milan, but later dropped his first name. His nickname was "Deerfoot." He was an outfielder for the Washington Senators throughout his playing career, from 1907 through 1922. During his final year he was a player-manager. He was also manager of the Senators in 1928, 1929, and from 1938 until his death. When not managing the Senators he managed minor league teams. He had a younger brother named Horace Milan who played for the Senators in 1915 and 1917. Clyde Milan player page at Baseball Reference.

Charpentier's most famous work, his 1900 opera "Louise" had its American premier at Hammerstein's Opera House in New York in 1908. It was presented again at the Metropolitan Opera House in 1911 and in 1913, with Mary Garden playing the lead in both productions. In 1914, his opera "Julien" (a sequel to "Louise" featuring the same lead characters) had its American premier at the Metropolitan, with Caruso in the title role, opposite Geraldine Farrar. New York Times, February 1, 1911 article on "Louise" revival. New York Times, February 5, 1913 article on "Louise" revival. The most likely occasion for the photo above is probably Charpentier's first visit to New York, in late 1913-early 1914, to rehearse the American premier of "Julien." New York Times, December 7, 1913 article announcing Charpentier's planned trip to America. New York Times, February 27, 1914 article on American premier of "Julian" at the Met.
