See books.google.com/books?id=XFnfnKg6BcAC&pg=PA131&l... for Bordoni's biography in Vaudeville, Old & New by Frank Cullen, Florence Hackman, Donald McNeilly. Her debut was November 20, 1912 in Broadway to Paris. The show only ran a few weeks but she became a popular vaudeville performer and clearly had a long career in vaudeville, on Broadway, in films, and even early TV, despite being in plenty of flops along the way!!

Cole Porter mentions her in "You're the Top": ''You're a prize, you're a night at Coney, you're the eyes, of Irene Bordoni." According to Robert Kimball, "Irene Bordoni was the performer who had the biggest impact on Porter because she introduced 'Let's Do It' and that was the song, in 1928, that put him on the map.'' George Wingfield (1876-1959) was an Arkansas native who settled in Nevada in 1896. He became one of the most powerful men in the state, building a fortune in mining, banking, ranching, and hotels. His financial empire collapsed in 1932, and he declared bankruptcy in 1935. Recovering from the disaster, he was able to build a second (though smaller) fortune, and remained an influential figure in Nevada for the rest of his life. The photo above may date from 1912, when Wingfield was offered (but refused) an appointment to the U.S. Senate, following the death of Republican Senator George S. Nixon, Wingfield's close friend and former business partner. Here's a web page about George Wingfield.

After a short, three-year break, here's some info on "J.P.C. Talbot" ; ) J.P.C. Talbot s/b J.F.C. Talbott J. F. C. Talbott (Joshua Frederick Cockey Talbott) also known as J. Fred C. Talbott (1843-1918), also known locally as "Uncle Fred", was a Democratic politician in Baltimore, Maryland. The former Maryland State Insurance Commissioner, leader of the Baltimore County Democrats and Congressman from Baltimore worked with Roger Sullivan during the 1912 Democratic Convention (which was being held in Baltimore) to support a conservative agenda. [1] [2] Talbott joined the Confederate Army in 1864, and served as a Private in the Maryland Calvary for the duration of the war. Admitted to the bar in 1866 he practiced in Baltimore County. He was prosecuting attorney for Baltimore County 1871-1875, a delegate to the Democratic National Convention for several years, and a twelve-term U.S. Congressman for the Second Congressional District of Maryland. [3] [4] In 1869, Fred Cockey Talbott married the former Laura Bell Cockey, daughter of the wealthy and influential John G. Cockey, president of the Tovvson National Bank in Maryland. [5] [6] He died while in office in 1918 and is buried in Cockeysville, Baltimore County, Maryland. [7] The USS J. Fred Talbott (DD-156) was named for him in 1918. Talbott was a member of the Naval Affairs Committee for 25 years and had worked unceasingly for a strong and modern Navy. [8]

Perhaps the American diplomat mentioned in NYT article on October 29, 1911. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B03E6DF1E31E233A... He was mentioned as former Second Secretary at the American Embassy in London, who had just spent two years on a "tour of the world."

Continuing ... He was in the news so often, it's impossible to suggest when the photo was taken. He had been a member of the First Regiment of Volunteer Cavalry (aka Roosevelt's Rough Riders) and figures frequently in the NYT society columns, including those from London. On May 17, 1912 the NYT published an article about a letter apparently written by Harry K. Thaw to a private detective in 1903. The version of the letter published in the New York Herald had a postscript included a list of names (including Craig Wadsworth) with some of them (not Wadsworth, but including Stanford White whom Thaw killed in 1906) annotated with the word "kill." The NYT article [ query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9507E1DA103AE633A... ] reports that the postscript was claimed to be a forgery by Thaw's lawyer. For more on the Thaw case, see www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2929579164/ NYT SOCIETY AT HOME AND ABROAD column on October 13, 1912, Sunday [ query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9504E1DB1F3CE633A... ] reported that Craig Wadsworth was heading for Europe on his way to Teheran to assume position of Secretary of the American Embassy there. He attended US Ambassador Whitelaw Reid's memorial service in London on Dec 20, 1912 and by that time had been appointed to the Bucharest Legation. Evelyn Nesbit, the young woman in the image, was a major celebrity in her day.  She started modeling in her early teens for many prominent artists, went on to become one of the famous "Gibson Girls", and also launched her own acting career. 

 At the very young age of 17, she was 'seduced' (today we'd call this rape) by highly-known and influential architect, Stanford White, of the architectural firm of McKim, Mead & White.  For many years thereafter, Nesbit, her mother, and her brother were the beneficiaries of financial support from White.  Nesbit eventually married multi-millionaire, unstable and violent, Harry Thaw.  Thaw had been obsessed for many years with architect S White, believing him to be committed to ruining his (Thaw's) reputation.  When Nesbit revealed to Thaw (who himself had battered and assaulted her on occasions), Thaw became determined to kill S White.  This he did, in public, shooting White in the face with a pistol, in around, I believe, 1910.  Thaw's trial for the murder of White was very big news at the time, and reported extensively in all papers around the country.  

Thaw was tried twice; during the first trial, a hung jury resulted, during the second, he was found not guilty by reason of temporary insanity and committed to an institution for the insane (from which he later escaped).  

Nesbit was forced to testify at both trials and to repeat lurid and provocative details of her relations (sexual and otherwise) with both men.  After this point, her reputation was irrevocably ruined, and, after being rejected by Thaw's extremely wealthy but cold and bizarre family, she struggled to support herself for the rest of her surprisingly long life:  Nesbit lived until the late 60's.  

Hard to believe a life spanning so much change in American society!

Her face should look familiar:  drawings, painting, prints of all kinds were made of her by many artists and designers throughout her youth, and one can still find these frequently reproduced.  One of the most well-known images of her is the profile drawing in black and white of a young, beautiful woman of the times, her hair piled upon her head and trailing down the back of her neck in a manner that resembles a question mark.  This print was entitled, "The Eternal Question".

The workmanship on this jacket is absolutely amazing.  Most likely created from a nicely woven wool.  The bond buttonholes would have been made by hand.  The times were filled with people who would be our current day "Makers".  Maybe the hat was a "Hack".
The fashion she is wearing could only have been created by her contemporary "Makers" and "Hackers".  I think that hat is a "remix".

@Sue, I'm confused by your comments.  Are you suggesting that the hat Nesbit wears in the original photo is not authentic, but was somehow photoshopped?  Far more elaborate hats were worn in Nesbit's day.  Some used the feathers so heavily of particular bird species that the species were driven to extinction.

Some interesting information from the Senate website: "During his years in the Senate, Sheppard was chairman of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, and he acted as Democratic whip between 1929 and 1933. He led the fight for adoption of the prohibition amendment to the Constitution and strongly supported women's suffrage. As a progressive Democrat, Sheppard advocated reform legislation promoting rural credit programs, child labor laws, and antitrust laws. Also among his list of accomplishments was the Sheppard-Towner Act, which provided for maternity and infant welfare, the Federal Credit Union Act, the Selective Service Act, and the Lend-Lease Act. Standing only five feet, four inches tall, he was a quiet man who was most effective behind the scenes rather than in active debate. Sheppard was a dedicated student of English literature who compiled an unpublished 35-volume work entitled Selected Comments of Shakespeare on Over 4,000 Subjects." A true hero

Inverted date written on negative is 5/16/12 #2. Pankhurst was sentenced (in London) to nine months jail on May 22, 1912 "convicted of conspiracy and incitement to commit damage, the charges arising out of the suffragist window-smashing campaign." See query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B02EEDA153CE633A... Photo apparently by Matzene of Chicago. She had been in Chicago in November 1909, according to NYT query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9400E6D81630E733A... She was there again in November 1913. Matzene appears to have registered a photograph in the same outfit hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3b34110 for copyright as of October 25 1913. Another LoC photo -- hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3b31732 -- is quite specifically a photo from 1909 copyrighted in 1913. So perhaps that's the case for the Matzene photos -- taken during the 1909 visit but copyrighted at the start of her 1913 visit. Pankhurst was held at Ellis Island for a day or two (Oct 18-20, 1913) with a deportation order issued, but later rescinded. Another picture by Matzene, dated as from the 1913 visit and in a different outfit is hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/mnwp.275016. Pin/brooch and ribbon are probably of some significance.

Joseph Edward Davies (November 29, 1876 - May 9, 1958) was the second Ambassador to represent the United States in the Soviet Union. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_E._Davies
Richard Arthur Norton (1958-): Thanks for the additional information on Davies. We'll add more details to the source data and then reload the description to Flickr.

A horrible person, to put it mildly. The tragic results of Davies seeming affinity for Stalin and the Soviet regime are detailed in the book, The Forsaken: An American Tragedy in Stalin's Russia , by Tim Tzouliadis (2008). From Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_E._Davies#Ambassador_to_the_... "Even after Americans living in the Soviet Union thronged the gates of the embassy in Moscow to plead for new passports to leave Russia (Stalin had taken their original U.S. passports for 'registration' purposes years before), Davies was unmoved. Though many were communists, others had moved to Soviet Russia as skilled auto workers to help produce cars at the recently-constructed GAZ automobile factory built by the Ford Motor Company. The American workers, suspected by Stalin of being 'poisoned' by Western influences, were dragged off with the others to Lubyanka Prison by the NKVD in the very same Ford Model A cars they had helped build, where they were tortured and either executed or exiled to Soviet gulags. Davies refused to lodge even a mild diplomatic protest, and later commented to the media: 'The Soviet Union is doing wonderful things. The leaders of the government are an extremely capable, serious, hardworking, and powerful group of men and women.'”

That mustache definitely belongs to Louise Bleriot (1872-1936), French engineer who flew a plane of his own design across the English channel in 1909: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Blériot

Inverted date on negative seems to read 5/26/27. Bleriot was in the news that day. On May 25, the previous day, he had entertained Charles Lindbergh to lunch and the meeting of theaviator who first crossed the English Channel and the aviator who first crossed the Atlantic was reported in the NYT on May 26, 1927. (subscription needed for access to full article) select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10C12F73C5F1773... LINDBERGH GREETS BLERIOT AS MASTER; Old Victor of English Channel Embraces Young Conqueror of the Atlantic. SEE BIG FUTURE IN THE AIR They Agree Transocean Service Is Possible With Financial and Technical Backing. LINDBERGH GREETS BLERIOT AS MASTER By CARLYLE MACDONALD.Copyright, 1927, by The New York Times CompanySpecial Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES.By CARLYLE MACDONALD. May 26, 1927, Thursday PARIS, May 25. -- Louis Bleriot, "the father of Old World aviation," whose flight across the English Channel from Calais to Dover just eighteen years ago was recorded to an unbelieving world, listened today with all the attention of a student to the opinions of Captain Charles A. Lindbergh as the American youth recounted for him the story of his flight from New York to Paris. .... However, I find myself wondering if that is really the date the photo was taken. A picture in an article from the same NYT shows a much older Bleriot and if he has a mustache it is much shorter.

A much more likely date (and location) for the picture -- in which Bleriot looks much the same as at the time of his 1909 flight across the channel -- is April 1912, when he came to New York on the France as part of celebration of Champlain. The stamp at lower right also has a date but is largely obscured. However, the first number is certainly 4. From query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C05E2DE153CE633A... FLOWER OF FRANCE BRINGS RODIN BUST; Distinguished Delegation, Bearing Champlain Memorial, In on New Liner France. April 27, 1912, Saturday The French delegation bringing over the bronze bust executed by Rodin, the gift of the French Nation, which is to be erected at Crown Point, Lake Champlain, N.Y., on May 3, in memory of Samuel de Champlain, the explorer, who discovered the lake on July 20, 1619, arrived yesterday on the new French liner France. See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2458991233/ for another picture (with only Andrew Carnegie identified) from the same trip. I think Bleriot is probably at the front left on that picture.

The lace on Mts. Blaney's dress is a very fine example of machine made chemical lace.  This method of making machine lace is more of an embroidery where cotton thread was embroidered on a different fiber that could be burnt out chemically after the embroidery was fininshed, leaving the lace like fabric.

This is probably Episcopalian Bishop Chauncey Bunce Brewster (1848-1941), subject of this very wordy 1942 biography available from the Internet Archive. He was descended from a William Brewster, a Pilgrim Elder who arrived on the Mayflower in 1620. In 1868 he graduated from Yale (where he was a member of the secret Skull and Bones society) and received an MA in 1871. Granted deacon's orders at Berkeley Divinity School in 1872, he served in churches in Connecticut, Michigan, New York, and Maryland before being named Bishop Coadjutor of Connecticut in 1897, the same year he received a Doctorate of Divinity from Trinity College. He was the Bishop of Connecticut from 1899 to 1928. Yale's Brewster Hall is named for him.

Robert Burns Brown (1844-1916) was an Ohio native who fought in the Civil War, as an ordinary soldier. He was awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for capturing a Confederate flag at the battle of Missionary Ridge in 1863. After the war he spent forty years working at the Zanesville Courier in Zanesville, Ohio. He joined the Civil War veterans fraternal organization, the Grand Army of the Republic, and eventually became its State Commander in Ohio, and then in 1906 the National Commander. It was from the G.A.R. that he received the honorary title of General. Here's a brief biography of him.

From 1925 to 1927 he served as US Attorney for the Southern District of New York, prosecuting a number of notable cases. Laura Jane Addams (September 6, 1860 – May 21, 1935) was a founder of the U.S. Settlement House movement, and the first American woman to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jane_Addams

Jane Addams was a social reformer, pacifist and women's rights activist who was most remembered as the founder of Hull House, one of the nation's first settlement houses which offered social, educational, and cultural opportunities to the large immigrant population of Chicago. In 1931 she, together with Nicholas Murray Butler, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. She was the first American woman to receive a Nobel Prize. In 1940 this 10¢ stamp was issued in the Famous Americans Series – Scientists, to honor and commemorate her.   First Day ceremonies were held in Chicago on April 26, 1940. (Scott 878). A 15-cent postal card in the Historic Preservation Series, marking the centennial of Hull House, was issued by the U.S. Postal Service in September, 1989. First Day ceremonies were held on September 16, 1989, at the Jane Addams Hull-House Museum—part of the College of Architecture and the Arts at the University of Illinois at Chicago. (Scott UX134).                            Jane Addams, 1940                        Hull House Centennial, 1989

swanq: Thanks for the background information on Mr. Addicks. Political Graveyard: Thank you for the date information on this photograph. (I found the image you mentioned in your photostream.) This photograph is part of the George Grantham Bain Collection (described here), which is made up of photos from the Bain News Service. In addition to producing their own photography, Bain would copy older images for use and distribution in publications, and this is one of those cases. It was copied by Bain, likely between 1910 and 1915, but the original dates from 1902 or earlier, as you've shown. Thank you for sharing this information!

This is the J.P. (Jack) Morgan Jr. residence at 228-231 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of 37th St. J.P. Morgan Sr. bought this house for Jack in 1904. Morgan Sr.'s house was on the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and 36th St. The Morgan Library's original entrance was on 33 E. 36th St. All three were connected by underground passageways. Person: James Otis Crandall (October 8, 1887 – August 17, 1951) was a right handed pitcher and second baseman. He was the first player to be consistently used as a relief pitcher. Consequently, he was given the nickname Doc by Damon Runyon who said Crandall was "the physician of the pitching emergency". He played from 1908 to 1918, first for the New York Giants, and then briefly for the St. Louis Cardinals in 1913 and than the Federal League with St. Louis from 1914 to 1916. Person: Frederick Carlisle Snodgrass (October 19, 1887 - April 5, 1974) was an American center fielder in Major League Baseball from 1908 to 1916 for the New York Giants and the Boston Braves. I see that the negative has the name "Cravath" on it, not Paskert. Unless this is another Bain error (not unthinkable), then this photo would depict Clifford Carlton "Gavvy" Cravath (1881-1963), a native of Escondido, California (some sources cite Poway, a nearby settlement), who played for the Phillies from 1912 through the end of his career in 1920. Previously he had played for the Red Sox, White Sox, and Senators, as well as playing semi-pro and minor league ball. Here's a biography of Gavvy Cravath from the Baseball Biography Project website. In case the Bain negative caption is wrong and this is actually Dode Paskert, here's some stuff about him, too: George Henry "Dode" Paskert (1881-1959) was a native of Cleveland, Ohio. He began playing in the minor leagues in 1904, and following three seasons in Dayton, Ohio, he played one season in Atlanta before starting his major league career with the Cincinnati Reds. He joined the Philadelphia Phillies in 1911, went to the Chicago Cubs in 1918, and returned to the Reds for his final season in 1921. The Baseball Biography Project has a fairly extensive biography of Dode Paskert.

An interesting sidelight to these old photos of Dodger players is that the Brooklyn team went through a number of name changes during its early years. Before joining the NL they had been variously known as the Atlantics, the Greys, the Grooms, and the Bridegrooms. If this photo dates from 1913, as indicated above, then the team was called the Brooklyn Superbas at the time. This was the name the team had adopted on joining the NL in 1899. They used the name Dodgers during the 1912 season (and maybe 1911- sources differ), but returned to their earlier name for the 1913 season. In 1914 they became the Brooklyn Robins, and then restored the name Dodgers in 1916. However, some sources say the team officially remained the Robins into the early 1930s. That the name Robins did continue in use at least into the 1920s is shown by various New York Times articles (such as this article of July 23, 1921) that use the names Robins and Dodgers interchangeably.

This building has been transported to  Carillon Park in Dayton. The historical society that manages Carillon Park has preserved many  local treasures like the Newcom Tavern, that is pictured here. 

If you are in the area, Carillon Park is a great place to visit.

Photo taken after great Dayton flood of March, 1913.  Newcom Tavern originally stood at the corner of Main and Monument Streets, but was moved to the levee in the 1930's when it was rediscovered under its clapboard siding and "restored." In the late 1960's the roof was temporarily removed and it was trucked two miles south of downtown to Carillon Park and reassembled and where it remains.

At the beginning of the twentieth century, baseball’s nascent American League, invaded cities with established National League teams. This occurred in Boston, Chicago and Philadelphia and created a ‘turf-war’ between the rival leagues. Many players ‘jumped’ leagues following larger salary offers, fostering a feeling of discontent between principles on both sides. The American League Baltimore franchise pondered a shift in home venue to New York (they would become the Yankees), furthering this simmering dispute. The manager of the National League New York Giants, John McGraw, commented to the press “the Philadelphia club is not making any money. It has a big white elephant on its hands.” Mr. McGraw’s pejorative statement of “white elephant” implied something odd, worthless and undesirable. Interestingly, Mr. McGraw had just himself ‘jumped’ from the American League Baltimore franchise to the New York National League franchise. Connie Mack, Philadelphia Athletics’ manager, and Ben Shibe the owner of the A’s defiantly adopted the white elephant as their mascot. The Philadelphia Athletics found success on the field and at the box office; the franchise was anything but a white elephant. The Oakland Athletics mascot remains an elephant, these days referred to as ‘Stomper.

John Bernard "Hans" Lobert (October 18, 1881 - September 14, 1968) was an American infielder, coach, manager and scout in Major League Baseball. Lobert was born in Wilmington, Delaware. Like shortstop Honus Wagner, a teammate of Lobert's when he first came to the major leagues, the German-American Lobert earned the nickname "Hans" as a familiar form of Johannes, the German version of his given name, and was dubbed "Hans Number 2" by Honus Wagner. Lobert batted only .274, but he played 14 seasons (1903, 1905-17) with five National League clubs, including regular stints as a third baseman for the Cincinnati Reds (1906-10) and Philadelphia Phillies (1911-14). He also played with the Pittsburgh Pirates (1903), Chicago Cubs (1905) and New York Giants (1915-17). During his career, Lobert was known as one of the fastest, if not the fastest, players in the game. He once raced a racehorse around the bases before a game. After managing in the minor leagues during the 1920s and early 1930s, Lobert became a coach for the Phillies from 1934 through 1941. At 60, he became one of the oldest rookie managers in baseball history when he was appointed skipper of the 1942 Phils, in the midst of the longest streak of futility in their history. Under Lobert, the club "improved" by losing only 109 games (they had lost 111 under Doc Prothro in 1941). Counting two losses as an interim manager in 1938, Lobert's career managing record was 42-111 (.275). After his one season at the Phillies' helm, Lobert's career in uniform ended as a Cincinnati coach (1943-44). He than became a scout for the Giants of New York and San Francisco, serving until his death in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania at age 86. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Lobert

From wikipedia:

Aaron S. Watkins (1863-1941), born in Ohio in 1863, was president of Asbury College in Kentucky. Before his ordination as a Methodist minister, he practiced law with his brother. He was the grandfather of Prohibition candidate for Vice President of the United States, W. Dean Watkins.

Long dedicated to promoting the temperance movement, Watkins served as Prohibition Party candidate for various political offices. These included:

    * Prohibition candidate for US Representative of Ohio 9th District, (1904)
    * Prohibition candidate for US Vice President, (1908 & 1912)

Watkins received honorary degrees of Bachelor of Science, Master of Science, Doctor of Laws, Doctor of Divinity, Doctor of Humane Letters and Doctor of Philosophy.

As noted by Ken and Gary above, the photo appears to be taken on April 8, 1913. President Woodrow Wilson made a speech on the floor of Congress recommending adjustment of tariff duties. A President had not addressed Congress personally since John Adams in 1800. A very similar, or perhaps the same photo by the National Photo Company is seen here: The Washington herald. [volume] (Washington, D.C.), 09 April 1913. Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress. (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1913-04-09/ed-...) Note the similar angle, and head movements of the people in the front row.

It seems that Henry Vallon was an opium dealer in NYC who may or may not have been involved with the murder of a gambler in 1912, for which police Lt. Charles Becker was eventually executed. www.oldandsold.com/articles01/article929.shtml "The police had no trouble getting track of the car with plate number NY 41313, in which the four men who shot Rosenthal got away. It was from a garage that rented out chauffeured cars. Driver Willie Shapiro was soon picked up. Close-lipped at first, Shapiro only admitted that he and the car had been hired for the night of July 15 by gambler Baldy Jack Rose. Baldy Jack, whose real name was Jacob Rosenzweig, was a crafty character and a handy man with cards. It later evolved that he was a stool pigeon as well as collector of graft for Lieutenant Becker, receiving 25 per cent as part of "The System." Baldy Jack testified in time that he had helped Becker grab $600,000 in under a year. He was also affiliated with Rosenthal and owned a part interest in the house at 104 West Forty-fifth. The two men who started out in the car with Baldy Jack turned out to be Sam Schepps and Harry Vallon. [...] Harry Vallon was Man Friday to Bridgie Webber, who owned a poker room at the northwest corner of Forty-second Street and Sixth Avenue, a notorious and crooked trap frequented by Becker and never raided. He was also Webber's partner in various stuss houses (stuss was a simplified version of faro, known on New York's East Side as Jewish faro). These three men told Shapiro to take them to Seventh Avenue and 145th Street, where they picked up Frank Cirofici, known as Dago Frank, small, hard, and poisonous in a deceptively quiet way, who was a stick-up man and gunman. He was often seen in company of Kid Benson, a big-time Harlem gambler he frequently protected, and his gun was also at the disposal of Big Jake Zelig's East Side gang." According to this article, Vallon came into the police station to deny being involved in the killing. He spent some time in jail, and at one point Becker clamed Vallon had pulled the trigger, but in the end four other men were convicted of the murder, and Becker of hiring them.

Apr 19, 1957
Mrs. De Meissner,102; Novelist and Translator 

Sophie Radford de Meissner, 102, widow of a Russian diplomat who was the first American woman to translate a Russian play into English, died yesterday at the Home for Incurables, 3720 Upton st. nw., after a long illness.

Owen Johnson (1878-1952) was a writer and war correspondent: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Owen_Johnson From the dates this should be his second wife (of five), Esther Ellen Cobb--they married in 1912 and divorced in 1917.

According to the Wikipedia article on Owen Johnson, [ en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Owen_Johnson ] "His first wife died in 1910. His second wife was Esther Ellen Cobb, whom he divorced in 1917. His third wife was Cecile Denise de la Garde, who died in 1918. His fourth wife was Catherine Sayre Burton, who died in 1921. His fifth wife was Gertrude Bovee Le Boutillier. He was the father of five children." So this is probably Esther Ellen Cobb, given the time frame of the Bain collection.

According to listsearches.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/ORLAKE/2008-03... which reproduces THE NEW ERA, ALTURAS, MODOC COUNTY, CAL of WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1912, "Miss Esther Cobb, a Lakeview [Oregon] girl who is well-known here and who has made a world-wide reputation for herself as an opera singer, was married on January 31st, 1912, in New York, to Owen Johnson, editor of The Century Magazine. So the photo could be from early 1912.

She went by Madame Cobina professionally, and later as Cobina Wright (and then Cobina Wright, Sr, to distinguish herself from her daughter), according to the following news articles. DIVORCES OWEN JOHNSON.; Nevada Decree for Mme. Cobina on Ground of Desertion. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A03EFD9123AE433A... "Full Dress" from TIME magazine of Monday, Feb. 11, 1935 has more about her second marriage, to William May Wright, of the New York Stock Exchange. She had an interesting life!! www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,748394,00.html?... Bio from IMDB at www.imdb.com/name/nm0942174/bio digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/id?TH-63318 is a picture of Cobina Wright, Sr. I can believe it's the same person.

This photo depicts Jefferson Monroe Levy (1852-1924), who owned Thomas Jefferson's house and farm, Monticello, from 1879 until 1923. He was a New York attorney who served three terms in the House of Representatives. J.M. Levy had (after many complications) acquired Monticello from the estate of his uncle, U.S. Naval Commodore Uriah Phillips Levy, who had bought it in 1836. A brief history of the Levys' work to preserve Monticello can be read on this page at Monticello.org. The page has links to a couple of other pages about the Levys.

Felix Isman was a vaudeville impresario and later a pioneer in motion picture exhibition. He was also an author and a real estate developer. He was a partner of the vaudeville team Weber and Fields in the Broadway Theatre in New York, acting as their producer. In 1924, his book "Weber and Fields : Their Tribulations, Triumphs and Their Associates" was published. A 1914 volume, "The Theatre of Science: A Volume of Progress and Achievement in the Motion Picture Industry" by Robert Grau, has a brief section on Isman, beginning on page 299. A PDF of the book is available from Google Books here, or find the Felix Isman references in it by using the "Search in this book" box about midway down that page.

perfgeek,  
My suspicion is that "vorne" here is more in the sense of "fore", as in "fore and aft," which describes the axis of a vessel from bow to stern.  When parts are constructed for later installation, it is usual to mark or label them to ensure they are installed the right way round.  So "vorne" probably indicates that the turbine is to be installed so that the tube facing us is pointing forwards in the ship.

Based on the box scores of the 1912 Series, I think this is a photo of Merkle stealing second in Game 4. www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1912/B10110NY11912.htm

Fred Merkle is probably best known for an unfortunate blunder that he made as a rookie in the heat of the 1908 pennant race between the Cubs and the NY Giants. In a 1-1 game in the bottom of the ninth, with Giants runners on first (Merkle) and third, a Giant player lined a single that brought in the supposed winning run. Giants fans stormed the Polo Grounds field, and in the chaos that ensued a Cubs player stood on second base with the ball. After a hasty conference, the umpires ruled that Merkle never touched second base and was ruled out on a force play. The game ended in a tie, rather than a Giants win, and the Cubs went on to win the pennant and the 1908 World Series. The verb "to Merkle," meaning to leave something incomplete, entered the American lexicon.

This article mentions two competitors for the Harmsworth Trophy including Montague Batting, the designer of the Mona, owned by the Marquis of Anglesea.. "Mr. Batting said that Mona was 26 feet long and had an 8 cyclinder Wolsely engine." Mr. Batting was to pilot tthe Mona in the race, competing against Tom Sopwith the English aviator, piloting Maple Leaf IV. another NYTimes article mentions Mr. Batting also: At Henley, Classic Boats To Cherish By WENDY MOONAN Published: July 2, 1999 Among motor boat enthusiasts, the vintage launch has always been the queen of the waterways... The rarest boat in the sale, Mr. Klein said, is Batboat II, a 21-foot-long hydroplane lake racing boat built in 1912 that is named for its British designer, Montague Batting. ''They didn't build very many of them, and they stopped making them in 1915, so few survive,'' Mr. Willis said. Created for the British International Trophy Races, Batboat II has a mahogany deck with an open cockpit fitted with a mahogany bench seat. The boat finished first in the 1913 trials, and was then sent to America where, Mr. Klein said, ''She was used for rum running on the Hudson River during Prohibition.'' Estimate: $9,500 to $14,250. query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A05E5D6173DF931A... Batting"&st=cse

Jess Willard (1881-1968) was a heavyweight boxer whose career lasted from 1911 to 1923. In 1915 he won the heavyweight championship, defeating Jack Johnson in a 23 round fight in Havana on April 5, 1915. Though Willard held the title for four years, he defended it only once during that time. He lost the championship to Jack Dempsey in one of the most brutal fights in boxing history (though it lasted only three rounds), on July 4, 1919, at Toledo, Ohio. BoxRec has a fairly detailed biographical sketch.
Jess Willard was a first cousin to my G,G, grandmother.
Joey Smith was a British featherweight who fought five bouts from 1909 to 1911. BoxRec bout list.

Nebraskan Luther McCarty (1892-1913)- not McCarthy, though his name was often misreported as such in the press of the time- was a heavyweight who began fighting professionally in 1911. On New Year's Day, 1913, he was declared "White Heavyweight Champion of the World" after defeating Al Palzer in a fight at Vernon, California. His promising career (his nickname was "Luck") was cut short when he died of a brain hemorrhage on May 24, 1913, shortly after being knocked out by Canadian boxer Arthur Pelkey two minutes into a fight at Calgary, Alberta. Pelkey broke down and cried on hearing the news of McCarty's death. His own career seems to have been adversely affected by the event. He lost the title in his next fight, on January 1, 1914, and though prior to the McCarty fight he had suffered only three losses and had won over twenty bouts, afterward he had only four wins in more than twenty fights. Tommy Gibbons was born in either 1891 (the year usually given) or 1894 (his own claim) and died in 1960. He was the younger brother of middleweight boxer Mike Gibbons. He began fighting professionally in 1911 and retired from the ring in 1925 after 94 wins, 5 losses and three draws. In 1923, he challenged heavyweight champion Jack Dempsey for the title, losing by a decision, though he became the only boxer to last a full 15 rounds with the Manassa Mauler. Like his brother, Tommy Gibbons was a hard hitter who gained a large percentage of his wins by KO. He was knocked out only once himself, in the twelfth round of his final fight, by future heavyweight champion Gene Tunney. He was inducted into the International Boxing Hall of Fame in 1993. BoxRec biography page. BoxRec bout list.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Gibbons en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tommy_Gibbons

Middleweight Mike Gibbons (1887-1956), the "St. Paul Phantom" was older brother of boxer Tommy Gibbons. Mike's ring career lasted from 1907 to 1922, and he is credited with 111 wins, 38 by KO. He lost only nine bouts, and was never knocked out in the ring himself. Mike Gibbons' BoxRec bout list page.

This is stretch & I might be totally wrong here, but bear with me. In the late 60's/early 70's there was a soap opera named "Dark Shadows". One of the main characters was played by an actress named Alexandra Moltke. Her IMDB bio says: "Daughter of a Danish count and diplomat, Carl Adam Greve von Moltke, and wife Mabel Wilson, and paternal granddaughter of Carl Greve von Moltke (1869-1935) and his American wife Cornelia Van Rensselaer Thayer, who had some Dutch American ancestry." Could this be Carl Greve von Moltke & his wife Cornelia?

The Moltke family was quite large, with branches in Denmark, Sweden and Germany. The Count might possibly be a Danish Moltke, but I think it more likely that he is the Helmuth Graf von Moltke (1876-1939) who is listed on this page that Google turned up at a genealogy website. If so, then the boy in the photo would be Helmuth James von Moltke (1907-1944), leader of the Kreisau Circle (named for the family's seat in Silesia), which opposed the Nazi regime during WWII. Helmuth James Graf von Moltke was arrested in 1944 and executed by the Gestapo in 1945. He is the subject of a Wikipedia article. Count von Moltke's wife was the former Dorothy Rose-Innes, daughter of the South African Jurist Sir James Rose-Innes.

There were two Moltke's who were very important German military officers, Chief of Staff both, elder one was uncle of younger one. Both very major figures in period leading up to WW1 and then during the war. Helmuth von Moltke the younger, was chief of the German general staff at outbreak of WW1 and a major figure in WW1. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmuth_von_Moltke_the_Younger His uncle was the military architect of the German victories of 1866 and 1870.

The two officers mentioned by Harry Angstrom are usually known as Helmuth von Moltke the Elder (1800-1891) and Helmuth von Moltke the Younger (1848-1916.) The uncle did not inherit the title of Graf (Count), but it was granted to him in 1870, for the services he rendered to the nation. The nephew never held a comital title, and thus could not be the Count in this Bain photo. If this photo does not depict a Danish Greve (Count) Moltke (about whom I can find nothing on the Internet), then he must be the heir of Wilhelm Graf von Moltke (1845-1905), whose ancestral title was tied to the ownership of Kreisau. As Helmuth Graf von Moltke zu Kreisau was born in 1876 (and would have inherited the title on the death of his father in 1905), and as his son, Helmuth James, was born in 1907, they would have been the apparent ages of the two Moltkes in this ca. 1910 photo.

This NYTimes article talks about a Danish count Carl Moltke who was the Danish minister to the US, who is being transferred to Berlin (August 7, 1912) query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9504E2DB123CE633A... there was also a famous German naval ship named the Moltke, info here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMS_Moltke_(1910)

An excellent discovery! A minister to the United States would be very likely to have had his picture taken for the press. If this is indeed Count Carl Moltke, then the boy is probably Carl Adam Moltke, father of the actress Alexandra Isles (nee Moltke) mentioned by captainslack in the first comment above. Here is a web page on which you can read an excerpt from a book about the von Moltke family, which includes an interview with Alexandra Isles. As Mrs. Isles was born in 1947, her father could well have been about the age of the boy in this photo at the time it was taken (he was born in Copenhagen on September 13, 1908, according to an entry near the bottom of this web page about the Van Rensselaer family.) The woman in the photo would, of course, be the former Cornelia Van Rensselaer Thayer. Perhaps Alexandra Isles, who is now a producer and director of documentaries (according to her Wikipedia biography) will come across this page and be able to tell us whether or not this photo depicts her father and grandparents.

www.cantabile-subito.de/Contraltos/Homer__Louise/haupttei... Louise Homer (1871-1947) was a Pittsburgh-born contralto working in the 1910s. She retired from the opera in 1919. She was also the mother of six children, and the aunt of composer Samuel Barber.

Louise starred as Marina in the first American production of Boris Godounow at the Metropolitan Opera in NYC in 1913. Interestingly, the Victor Book of Opera shows a different woman in this same costume with the caption "Homer as Marina." Also in the cast were Paul Althouse as Dimitri, Adamo Didur as Godounow, Anna Case as Theodore, Maria Duchene as the nurse, and Leonora Sparkes as Xenia.

This photo was taken of the funeral procession of Col. John Jacob Astor IV on May 4, 1912, as it entered Trinity Church Cemetery. An estimated 5,000 people came to watch the funeral, although only a few with special passes were admitted past the cemetery gate. The view is eastward up the steep block along West 155th Street from Riverside Drive, toward Broadway. The buildings to the left are part of the Audubon Terrace complex (1908) that housed the Hispanic Society of America, the American Academy of Arts & Letters, the Museum of the American Indian-Heye Foundation, the American Geographical Society, the American Numismatic Society and the Church of Our Lady of Esperanza.

The ship "Finland" was chartered by the U. S. Olympic Committee to carry the American Olympic Team to the 1912 Summer Olympics in Stockholm, Sweden. It departed New York harbor on June 14, 1912 (the scene photographed above), and served as training and living quarters for the team as it crossed the Atlantic and during the games as well, when it was stationed in Stockholm harbor as a floating hotel. Members of the American track and field team at the 1912 Summer Olympics in Stockholm. The questioned name should be spelled Kiviat. Ralph Waldo Rose (1884-1913) won the gold medal in men's two-handed shot put. Patrick Joseph McDonald (McDonnell-) (1887-1954) won the gold for men's shot put and silver for men's two-handed shot put. Matthew John McGrath (1877-1941) took the gold medal in men's hammer throw. John Paul Jones (1890-1970) won no medals. Albert Richard "Abel" Kiviat (1892-1991) won silver in the men's 1,500 metre run and gold in the men's 3,000 metre run.

It is really amazing how the players were able to catch the ball one handed with the old gloves that had no webbing or lacing between the fingers.  This glove in the photo has longer fingers than most gloves of that time.  The ball was not wound as tight as it is today, thus making it a bit softer, what they called the Dead Ball.  Therefore, there were few home runs hit and many of the ones that were hit were inside the park.  Batters tended to face the pitcher more so that they could see the ball better and then punch at the ball trying to place it between the fielders.  The bats had thicker handles, also.  Overall, the players were smaller and not as athletic as they are today.  They didn't believe in muscle building and conditioning like today's players.  In fact, weight training was discouraged because it was felt one would become "muscle bound" and not be able to throw well.  This attitude was still popular into the 1960's.  I can remember coaches also telling us to not go swimming because it would tire us out for baseball.  At any rate, I find it interesting that the bases are still 90 feet apart and the batter is usually always thrown out on a ball hit to any infielder, just as in circa 1900.  Today's players are faster, have better equipment, are more physical, but it is still a game of inches.  Ruth came along and changed the game.  Players started to swing for the fences like the Babe.  The ball was wound tighter and other sluggers such as Jimmy Foxx and Hack Wilson emerged.

"The launch of the Imperator took place on May 23, 1912. The German Kaiser Wilhelm II had taken enormous interest in Ballin’s new trio, and now he was the one to lead the ceremony. Just below where the Imperator’s giant bow towered an ornamented platform had been built for the Kaiser and his staff. The Kaiser himself had dressed in his Admiral suite and he ascended the platform together with Albert Ballin [the ship's creator]. After the Kaiser’s speech when he was just to christen the ship, a piece of lumber fell from the ship’s bow and nearly hit the sovereign. This was seen as a bad omen by many, but the ceremony ended happily, at least." From Imperator/Berengaria: 1913 - 1938 from the Great Ocean Liners website.

The Kaiser loved the military and he loved his uniforms (article above mentions him dressing in his admiral's uniform). He would lead Germany and the entire world into the disastrous World War One in which many millions of soldiers and civilians were killed. Most European countries lost more soldiers in WW1 than in WW2. Imperator Im`pe*ra"tor\, n. [L. See Emperor.] (Rom. Antiq.) A commander; a leader; an emperor; -- originally an appellation of honor by which Roman soldiers saluted their general after an important victory. Subsequently the title was conferred as a recognition of great military achievements by the senate, whence it carried wiht it some special privileges. After the downfall of the Republic it was assumed by Augustus and his successors, and came to have the meaning now attached to the word emperor. George I, King of Hellenes, was a Danish prince who was elected king by the Greek people in 1863. He ruled for 50 years but was assassinated during the Balkan Wars on March 18, 1913. He was the grandfather of England's Prince Phillip. He lay in state in Greece for five days, so the services here would have coincided with his funeral in Greece.

7th March 1913: Suffragettes jailed for Kew Gardens blaze Two women were sent to jail for an arson attack which destroyed the tea pavilion at the Royal Botanic Gardens in Kew, west London. Lilian Lenton and Olive Wharry, Suffragettes linked to the Women's Social and Political Union, had been arrested nearby on the night of the fire. Found guilty, they were sentenced to 18 months imprisonment at the Old Bailey in central London. Both were sent to Holloway prison in north London to serve out their sentences but immediately went on hunger strike, saying that they would not eat until they were released. Lenton was quickly freed after she became seriously ill following an attempt by the prison authorities to force-feed her. After a 32-day hunger strike, which she apparently managed to keep a secret from the guards, Wharry was also released. Source www.london-today.net/web/events/march/7/00003218/10251353...

My father Stanley J Rowland, (born 1894) a solicitor's clerk aged 19, was sent in 1913 with a fellow junior clerk named Cowling to serve the writ on Olive Wharry at her home at Whitstone Head, Whitstone, in North Cornwall, near Bude. They cycled out to Whitstone from their employer's office in Holsworthy, about 8 miles, and were admitted by her father Dr Wharry. When they explained their business he refused to let them see his daughter and locked them in his study. After a long while they were released and told to leave, taking the writ with them. As they left one of them flung the writ on the doorstep. This was held to be effective service. Dr Wharry flew into a rage and, calling his servants, chased them off the premises. Dr Wharry was subsequently prosecuted for assaulting a process server acting in the course of his duties and stood trial at the Old Bailey in London, initially pleading Not Guilty. My father and his colleague were ordered to attend as prosecution witnesses. Neither had been east of Exeter before and it was a great adventure. When they arrived in London they were told that the case would start a day late. The only place in London they had heard of was Madam Tussaud's waxworks and so they spent the day there. In the event Dr Wharry changed his plea to Guilty and their evidence was not required. My father had never before then slept a night away from home. The writ to be served on Miss Wharry related to the arson at Kew but I do not know if it was a civil claim for damages or a criminal summons. James M Rowland

American featherweight boxer Joe "Kid" Coster (1889-1974) was born Joseph Agnello in Palermo, Sicily. His ring career lasted from 1906-1914. Thumbnail biography at Cyber Boxing Zone.

The Dobbs in this photo must be Robert "Bobby" Dobbs (1869-1930), an American lightweight who, after a long and highly successful boxing career in the United States, went to Europe in 1902 and racked up a considerable number of victories on the continent and in the UK over the next dozen years. Bout list at BoxRec. Thumbnail biography at Cyber Boxing Zone which says that after retiring from the ring he ran a gym and training facilities for boxers. Here's another Bain photo of Dobbs, probably taken about the time of his July, 1910 bout with Danish boxer Holger Hansen. I can't identify with any certainty the Edwards in the photo above, but Dobbs did twice fight a boxer who went by the name Australian Billy Edwards, in Cardiff, Wales, but both of those bouts took place in 1905- perhaps the wrong period for this Bain photo. Another possibility is that the Edwards in this photo is one of the younger boxers Dobbs worked with after his retirement. If so, then it might be the best-known boxer named Edwards during that period, Artie Edwards, whose ring career ran from 1911-1922. Unfortunately, I can't find photos of either Edwards on the Internet.

There are three Bain News Service Photos captioned “Dutch Treat Club in Annual Feast and Frolic” in the March 8, 1914, New York Times. Included is a photo of James Montgomery Flagg “As He Seemed to the Dutch Treaters”. Appearing in the other photographs is Jack Hines, Miss Dorothy Meyers, Arthur William Brown, G. B. Baker, J. W. Adams, H. G. Dart and A. B. Walker. — From The Library of Congress American Memory Collection.

An illustrated article in the Sacramento Union details a 1910 meeting of the club, featuring both Flagg and George Grantham Bain, a subject of a Flagg caricature: "Futures in Cartoons Are Originated by Artist Flagg Dutch Treat Club Witnesses the Works of a Pioneer In Portraiture. THESE striking cartoons were made at the annual dinner of the Dutch Treat club of New York city by James Montgomery Flagg, the well-known artist and illustrator. They are “lightning sketches’’ of members of the club, made while they were on their feet, speaking. They show the members as Mr Flagg imagined they might look in 1940. It was a unique feat of the imagination, and Mr. Flagg perhaps has opened a new field of art. It is not unusual for persons who have their portraits painted to want twenty or thirty years taken from their age by the painter. Shall we develop a fad for futurities in portraiture? If so, Mr. Flagg can claim to be the pioneer. The cleverness of these cartoons, as shown by comparison with the originals. appears all the more striking when it is known that Mr. Flagg did them while on his feet at an easel, without preparation, and that each of them consumed but a few minutes In its execution. These are representatives of some eight or ten sketches which Mr. Flagg did during the course of the dinner, including future portraits of Thomas L. Masson of Life, J. O. H. Cosgrave of Everybody's, Orson Lowell, Ellis Jones, Ellis Parker Butler, W. O. Inglis of Harper’s. These cartoons are of Burges Johnson, the humorist, and George Grantham Bain, the magazine writer and syndicate manager. The Dutch Treat club is a unique organization. It has 100 members, all artists, literary men, publishers or architects. It meets once a week for an informal luncheon, at which every member pays his own shot, hence the club’s name. The officers of the club are Thomas L. Masson, president, and J. Montgomery Flagg, treasurer." cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SU19100307.2.25&e...
A series of Bain photos of Flagg caricatures of artists and writers, likely from the Dutch Treat club functions, are part of this project, and see www.flickr.com/search/?text=flagg%20caricature
The caricatures of Bain and Burges Johnson, from 1910 are in the LOC Bain collection, but are not yet part of the Commons and can be found here: www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=1006&co=ggbain

Saint Thomas Church, located at the corner of 53rd Street and Fifth Avenue in the borough of Manhattan, New York, New York in the United States, is an Episcopal parish church of the Episcopal Diocese of New York. It is also known as Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue or as Saint Thomas Church in the City of New York and was incorporated on January 9, 1824. The current structure, completed in 1914, is the fourth church built to house this congregation and was designed by the architects Ralph Adams Cram and Bertram Grosvenor Goodhue in the French High Gothic style. This is a photograph of the ceremonies held on March 20, 1913, to mark the opening of 9 new firehouses in New York City. The firehouse at 111th Street (and Engine 91), was one of the nine new firehouses celebrated that day. FIRE ALARM TO OPEN 9 NEW FIREHOUSES New York Times  March 11, 1913
"Unusual ceremonies will mark the opening on Thursday afternoon, March 20, [1913], of the nine new firehouses which are to house ten new companies. Mayor Gaynor will start the companies for their new stations by turning in an alarm from the City Hall, [photo] and later in the day he will award the Fire Department medals to the men who have been selected for distinguished service." [more]
Engine 91 of the New York Fire Department (FDNY) was placed in service on March 20, 1913. [1]   Ladder Company 43 was originally quartered with Engine 91 and Battalion 25 in 1913. Ladder 43 later moved to new quarters at 1836 2nd Ave.[2] Engine 91 was housed at 244 E. 111th Street, in Manhattan -- proudly known then, and now as "Spanish Harlem". The firehouse exists to this day, and houses the latest iteration of Engine 91. Both the firehouse and the latest version of Engine 91 have been used as set locations for major television and motion picture productions, including the  FX series Rescue Me. [3] While there isn't a date when the 1913 Engine 91 was removed from service, there was a replacement put in service on Jan 1, 1916.   Engine 91 – Then and Now (95+ years later)       "FDNY Engine 91, NYC (2008)"   by jag9889           "Engine 91 - 1st trip (1913)        by LOC

Regarding rockcreek's note about the swastika symbol on the car--the use of the swastika as part of the logo of the KRIT Company is mentioned in the Wikipedia article and this article from The Detroit News, 16 January 2000. And here is a photo of a KRIT car with the symbol from another Flickr user. Looking at the photo large, I can see a similar logo above the radiator on this car--seems to identify it as a KRIT car. Perhaps some car fanatic out there can tell us the exact model. This use of the swastika symbol, of course, predates its adoption by Nazi Germany--it was a widespread symbol in many cultures, see, for instance Wikipedia and history1900s.about.com/cs/swastika/a/swastikahistory.htm. The latter has a good summary of its use at the time of this photo: Even in the early twentieth century, the swastika was still a symbol with positive connotations. For instance, the swastika was a common decoration that often adorned cigarette cases, postcards, coins, and buildings. During World War I, the swastika could even be found on the shoulder patches of the American 45th Division and on the Finnish air force until after World War II.
The swastika is a symbol which predates the third reich by a millennium or two. It's an ancient buddhist symbol, and many aboriginal American tribes used it.

I don't believe this is a K-R-I-T motor car. It's an open-top bus. K-R-I-T didn't make unusual vehicles like this. They made mainly small automobiles, like Roadsters and Runabouts. Their cars had small swastikas on their bronze hub caps, with the word K-R-I-T in large bronze letters across the front of the radiator. The top of the radiator shell was peaked, not flat, like the one on the bus in this photo. See the photo of the 1910 model in the Detroit News article mentioned above. The 1912 models were almost identical.  Moreover, car makers didn't paint large corporate logos on the sides of the hoods.

Something else is going on here. This bus has a number 10 on the side of the front seat, suggesting it's part of a fleet. The swastika could be the logo of a local transportation company.

Here are some scans of genuine K-R-I-T trade literature from around 1910:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/15283643@N04/3964041145/]

I don't see any connection.

whyaduck--that sounds correct for "Jacky". Here are some song lyrics referring to Jacky Tar or Jackie Tar. A quote from the liner notes on one album says: A Jacky Tar is a name for a sailor. Partridge's Concise Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English (New York: MacMillan, 1989) has an entry for Jackies = "American Sailors", and notes usage since at least 1942--clearly it was in use earlier. The usage seems to have gone from "Jack Tar" to "Jackie Tar" to Jackies.
Reverse handwriting at bottom says, "Inauguration Wash 1913," so this was part of Wilson's first inaugural parade.

Charles W. Morse (1855?-1933), a speculator and stock promoter who was 49 years old in 1904, at the time his second marriage was annulled, as described in this New York Times article. The article describes Morse as "...the promoter of the American Ice Company and an officer of about thirty banks and other corporations in this and other cities." It also notes that he had been a widower with three sons and a daughter. Perhaps the dapper young fellows flanking him in this photo were two of his sons? Morse had a hand in the Panic of 1907, during which stocks on the New York exchange lost half their value. In 1908, Morse was convicted of misappropriating funds of the Bank of North America. He was sentenced to federal prison, though he did not begin serving his term until 1910. Early in 1912, he managed to convince physicians that he was near death, and President Taft commuted his sentence ("MORSE PARDONED IN DEATH'S SHADOW" cried the New York Times headline on January 19, 1912. After his release, Morse miraculously recovered, and went on to outlive Taft by three years (and to be depicted in this Bain photo, which appears to date from 1915.) Though Morse has no Wikipedia article, Taft's biographer Henry Pringle devoted considerable space to the Morse affair, with lots of background information about Morse himself, and this section of Pringle's 1939 book can currently be read online on this web page.

The Rovert Building was sold in 1913: this NYTimes story: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9807E0D6123BE633A... says "A Fifth Avenue sale representing an investment of nearly $500,000, formed the important feature of the market yesterday. These are in all probability irregulars who possibly fought on the Greek side during the Macedonian Struggle (1904-1908) a guerrilla campaign that pitted Greeks against Bulgarians for the control of the southern part of the region of Macedonia then still under Ottoman rule. See the photo below of Greek fighters from Monastir whose clothing appears very similar to that of the irregulars above. Also note the long guns of the irregulars, most likely variants of the Mannlicher-Carcano rifle, an Italian version of an Austrian design that was adopted by the Hellenic royal army in the late 19th century. The Mannlicher was used extensively during the Macedonian Struggle (and much later gained permanent notoriety as the gun Lee Harvey Oswald used to allegedly shoot President John Kennedy).

Wystan, I agree with you that General Booth's funeral was held at Olympia on August 27. It appears that his remains were taken to International Headquarters overnight for his funeral procession the next day, August 28. Although it sheds no light on the dates, here is a pretty good film clip about the events: www.youtube.com/watch?v=fmVqoGzp3-o I tend to think that the event photographed above may have been part of the funeral procession on August 28.

Bob, I hadn't realized that the Procession was a separate event. That film is fascinating, and shows the amazing turnout that day, of mourners and the curious. The New York Times report puts the date of the Procession on August 29. NYT story, August 30, 1912: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E06E3D91630E2...

Wystan - I don't want to give the impression that I actually knew that the funeral and procession were on consecutive dates without having to search for it. That's not the sort of thing bouncing around in my head. I have seen the date of the funeral/procession vary across the August 27/28/29 including in some online archived newspaper accounts published here in Australia - so I'm not 100% certain. Here's an example published in Australia one month after the event: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article5339166 I would like to check the Times of London report, which would probably be authoritative but it's behind a paywall. As one would expect of such a significant figure there are several published biographies and I can tell from limited previews and snippets at Google Books that some have extensive accounts of these events - but I could not come up with a conclusive, authoritative date because I could not read the full texts. An example of misdating appears in the otherwise excellent National Library of France which carries a photograph showing a similar scene to that above, dated 31-8-12 : gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b6921189t.item.r=william+bo...

"Hindu" was more or less their nationality at the time. There wasn't really any such thing as "India"; the British colony was under the control of the British East India Company, but it was popularly called "Hindustan".

Dr. Doyen sounds like a prick. I'm glad my medical treatments aren't filmed and photographed and displayed in circuses around the world!

Fnarf, thank you for the history lesson.  I should know these sorts of things.  I certainly remember Hindustan, but I thought India was the name of the continent for five hundred years or so.
Oh, and I wondered about the gurney, also.  I mean, what did they use, a baby's gurney?  Certainly you do not want the feet hanging down during procedure so as to discourage clots.

This is probably a staged photo.  The twins appear to be dead, yet the surgeons are set up as if they are about to separate them by disecting a the thin skin band that joins them at the chest.  A true separation would have been a much more complicated procedure, and educated surgeons, even at that time would have known so.
Only one died after surgery, the other lived for a year or so.
PS, if they were dead, their legs would be straight very soon
PPS, It does not matter now, does it?
Disturbing and amazing -- Seen in my contacts' photos. (?)

Seems to me that the reason for the short gurney was to allow the cameraman a full and unobstructed view of the procedure.

I agree with Mr. DaKidd that we must strive to see this moment in its historical contest. That said, clearly these surgeons were ahead of their time for trying to bring a sense of normalcy to these twin girls' lives.

Well, they appear to be connected just by chest skin.  This would be a fairly simple procedure even back then.  Certainly it would be much more easy to recover from such a procedure than, say, an amputation which was a very common surgical technique back then, especially during and after the Civil War which was a half century before this photo.  Infection of the wound would really be the only serious concern if this is the only linkage between the two children.  The smaller girl probably died just due to the fact she was more frail and perhaps had some other internal problems.

Also, I am thinking that the photo was taken before the children were given a general, just to show how the surgeon was going to make his incision.
I agree that this is definitely staged. Actual surgery was no doubt done later, and not necessarily in the setting depicted,
This is disturbing!  Poor children.

This is the 1913 groundbreaking for the never-completed National American Indian Memorial: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_American_Indian_Memorial

Date is 22 February 1913 according to the Wikipedia article on the event. More on Rodman Wanamaker. The article on the memorial mentioned above mentions: Also in attendance were 32 or 33 American Indian chiefs, including Red Hawk and Two Moons. Red Hawk was a Sioux and Two Moons was a Cheyenne. It would probably be possible to identify some of the more prominent Native Americans in the photos. Red Hawk was very famous--a photo of him from 1907 is here, and a short Wikipedia article with photo of Two Moons. I have made some tentative identifications on the photo, but it is hard to say. There is a New York Times article from 23 February 1913 about this event. It is quite lengthy, with some biographical information on the participants, but there are no detailed captions for the photos.

rockcreek and cotinis:

Thanks to both of you for the additional information about this photograph and the event it depicts.  It is difficult to make definitive identifications of all the individuals shown, but we can at the least add more details about the ceremony to this record.

The tall native third from right is Jack Redcloud, son of the famous Lakota chief who was known as Redcloud and who won a war with the United States in 1866--Redcloud's War, of course.  Redcloud, the father, was a great man, brave, wise, stubborn, and infamous in his youth for killing the tyrant Bull Bear.

clickr100: Thank you for the identification of Jack Red Cloud! Other photographs in the Prints and Photographs Division's holdings, particularly this one by Edward Curtis, can certainly serve as additional proof of his identity. We will update the source data and reload the description to Flickr.

The Cheyenne Chief Two Moons stands second from left on this photo!!! First from left is Cheyenne Chief Wooden Leg. To the right from Rodman Wanamaker stands Crow Chief Plenty Coups, Crow Chief Medicine Crow, Crow man White Man Runs Him...

Wanamaker was adopted into the Crow Tribe by Chief Plenty Coups in late November of 1921.  Hairy Moccasin, White Man Runs Him and Curley, Crow scouts at the Battle of the Little Bighorn, were all in attendance at Wanamaker's adoption at Crow Agency and the Little Bighorn Battlefield.  Source Billings Gazette, November 27, 1921.  The fact that Two Moons and Wooden Leg, both who fought against Custer and the Crows, are in attendance, makes me think this was photographed at the Little Bighorn Battlefield.  It does not look like a sunny late June afternoon during a Custer re-enactment event, but you never know in Montana.

Red Hawk was closely associated with the Crazy Horse people (Oglala) who would end up at Pine Ridge.  His father was also known as Red Hawk.  I believe Red Hawk surrendered with Crazy Horse in 1877, but I'm not sure if this was the older or younger Red Hawk.  Many old people stayed out with Crazy Horse until his surrender in December; though many began to trickle into the reservation when things became to brutal, cold, uncertain.  Those who stayed out with Crazy Horse were certainly the die-hards among the Oglala.  I own the surrender ledger.  However, many warriors gave false and inappropriate names in order to show disdain for what they were being forced to do.  I'll check it.

Two notable Native Americans mentioned in the Wikipedia article on this event are Red Hawk of the Sioux and Two Moons of the Cheyenne. There are several photos of Red Hawk on the Internet, including one from the LOC. I am not sure if either of them are shown in this photo. Seems like there should be photos with complete captions somewhere, such as in the New York Times. The date of the dedication is given by the Wikipedia article as "On a rainy Washington's Birthday in 1913". At that time, that was celebrated on 22 February, the actual birthday, so the date of this would appear to be 22 February 1913.

The men featured in the image are not Sioux.  They appear to be from a rocky mountain tribe to the west of where the Sioux lived.  The floral motif in the beadwork gives it away as the Sioux were famous for their "lazy" stitch which was rigidly geometric.  The drooping breast plates are common among the Crow (Absarokee), a tribe that lived in the plains and mountains--fierce enemies of the Sioux (Lakota).  However these men lack the Crow hairstyle which included a distinctive bang .

This picture is of three Crow Chiefs. From left to right, Whiteman runs him, Plenty Coup, Medicine Crow. Whiteman runs him is my great great grandfather. I am a direct decendent of Whiteman runs him. He was the War Chief and Lead Scout for Custer during the Battle of the Little Big Horn. And he was chosen to be the model for the statue that Rodman Wanamaker had invisioned. He was molded in plaster in his full regalia, and I am searching for any infomation leading to finding that mold. I can be contacted at cjaystewart92@yahoo.com

There was a German athlete named Josef Waitzer, who competed in the 1912 Olympics at Stockholm. However, this Bain diptych depicts two different athletes. From the negative caption it appears that Waitzer is the mustachioed fellow on the right, but I've found no references to Waitzer participating in the shot put. Waitzer's Olympic events were the javelin throw, discus throw, and pentathlon. Still, this photo probably does depict Josef Waitzer (I'd considered the possibility that this was a Bain caption error.) There's a small photo of Josef Waitzer in 1930 on this web page, older and stockier but still resembling the guy in this photo. By that time he was Reichssportminister, according to the caption.

There is a Wikipedia article on Sokol, which was the Czech version of the German Turnverein and other such youth athletic organizations which were part of a late 19th century mania for physical culture. The mass gatherings were called Slets, and are still held today. Here you can see one Flickr user's photos tagged with sokol. You can also Google "sokol slet" to find a YouTube video promoting the 2009 Sokol Slet to be held in Fort Worth, Texas.
Thanks for the additional information. We'll add it to the source data and reload the description.

From The Czech Sokol Organization website:
VI. festival 1912 was a social event of the Federation "Slavonic Sokol" and lasted five weeks. More than 30 000 Sokols participated and competed and ten times more people came to see it. Sokols from the USA, France and Slavic countries performed there as well. The scene "Marathon" with 1500 participants was dedicated to the ancient Greek culture. It was a great encouragement to our nation.

Note that the handwritten caption on the photo says "Crown Prince Sweden," not "Seden."

The Crown Prince in the photo must be Gustav VI Adolf, who was King of Sweden from 1950 to 1973. He was born in 1882, and had close ties to England, having been married in 1905 to Princess Margaret of Connaught, a Granddaughter of Queen Victoria.

Here is a photo of Gustav VI Adolf and family taken in 1912. Looks like a plausible match. Surely that is some other Swedish dignitary on the right--he seems very formally dressed. An Uncle, perhaps? Seems like this visit (if it is in the US) should show up in the New York Times. I did a quick search, but did not see it.
The caption mentions English football players, so I'd surmise this photo was taken in England. A number of other photos in the Bain collection were taken in England.
Thanks for catching the misspelling and providing additional information. We'll update the source data and reload the description in Flickr.

You're right, whyaduck, but a number of photos were taken in Sweden too (including a few adjacent to this one in the LoC photostream)

Prior to 1947, though, England played Sweden only once in England, in Hull in November 1909, and a) the Crown Prince doesn't look dressed for a howling North Sea November gale, and b) I can't really see him making the journey to Hull in any case.

It's more likely to be either Göteborg on 1908-09-08  (Sweden lost 1 - 6) or Stockholm on 1914-06-10 (Sweden lost  1 - 5).

They did also play in London in the 1908 Olympic Games (lost 1-12) though, where the Great Britain side was actually the English amateur team (because Scotland, Ireland and Wales refuse to allow players to represent Great Britain at football).
JosefM: Thanks for the additional information. You clearly know much more about football than I do.

The 1912 Olympics were in Sweden and there are other photos from Sweden in the Bain collection on Flickr (e.g., www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2536795168/ ). Great Britain won the gold for football (soccer). According to www.sok.se/inenglish/stockholm1912.4.18ea16851076df636228... "Before an audience of 25,000, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf declared the Olympics opened on the 6th of July at the Olympic Stadium. A total number of 327,288 would get to see the Games, which took place under a clear blue Stockholm sky. By the way, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf had been very active in the preparations for the Games and his involvement was very significant." So this may be from 1912. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Football_at_the_1912_Summer_O... for a photo of the 1912 team. It seems to be in the same stadium -- look at the decorations above the stands. And I see the same goalie in both pictures. Some other players could be the same too.

swang: You're probably right about the time and place of this photo. It looks to me as though there are indeed several of the same players in both pictures, and it's surely the same stadium with the same decorations.

Here is another Bain photo of a Curtiss flying boat. Glenn Curtiss tested his flying boats on Lake Keuka, one of the Finger Lakes in upstate New York. He lived in Hammondsport, at the south end of the lake. His first flying boat, the Model E, or Flying Fish, was built in 1912, and is depicted in the photo on this page at the website of the U.S. Centennial of Flight Commission. I'd say it's the same plane in this Bain photo. This New York Times article of November 23, 1912, describes the test of the craft the previous day. The flying boat in the Bain photo to which I linked in my first paragraph above has a slightly different design—especially noticeable in the tail—and I suspect it may be Curtiss's second such craft, the America, built in 1914.

Cal Delaney (birth name Harold J. Delaney) (1893-1954) was a Lightweight active in the ring from 1911 to 1923. Bout list at BoxRec. Johnny Kilbane (John Patrick Kilbane, 1889-1957) was a World Champion Featherweight whose boxing career ran mainly from 1907 to 1923, though he had one fight in 1934. Bout list at BoxRec. Kilbane won a decision over Delaney at Akron, Ohio, on October 11, 1915. The pair had also fought a five round exhibition match at Cleveland, Ohio, on March 1, 1913. I can't find any other matches between them. Johnny Kilbane went on to serve in the Ohio State Senate and the Ohio State House of Representatives during the 1940s. There is a web site about him.

The name "Sterart" is a typo. This is Jim Stewart (1887-1918; birth name Henry John Loerch), a heavyweight bare-knuckle boxer who fought professionally from 1907 to 1917. There's a recognizable photo of him at Cyber Boxing Zone, and at his BoxRec biography page there's a cigarette card, apparently made from this Bain photo. Among his opponents was Ed "Gunboat" Smith, subject of this Bain photo. They fought in New York on May 9, 1912, and had a rematch in the same city the following October 21. Stewart died in the Influenza epidemic in 1918.

For a guy with such a big belt, Joe Turner is hard to track down. A couple of web sites mention a Joe Turner who held the Police Gazette Gold Belt as middleweight wrestling champion. This 1998 article by Bill Foley of the Florida Times-Union tells of Turner defending his title in a January 19, 1920 bout in Jacksonville. This page about an historic row house on 14th Street in Washington D.C. says (in the penultimate full paragraph) that Joe Turner's funeral was held in the Hines Funeral Home in that building, and that he had operated the Kit-Mar Restaurant and Arena nearby. The page also claims a link to his obituary, but the link's destination has apparently been altered since the page was last updated and only reaches a spammy site. This Wrestling Graveyard page gives the date of his death as February 18, 1947, and says he is buried at Cedar Hill Cemetery in Washington. Someone with access to Washington newspaper archives might check them to see if his obituary can confirm that this was the same Joe Turner in the Bain photo. It probably was. www.loc.gov/loc/lcib/9803/suffrage.html On Feb. 12, with cameras clicking, 16 "suffrage pilgrims" left New York City to walk to Washington for the parade. Many other people joined the original hikers at various stages, and the New York State Woman Suffrage Association's journal crowed that "no propaganda work undertaken by the State Association and Party has ever achieved such publicity." One of the New York group, Elizabeth Freeman, dressed as a gypsy and drove a yellow, horse-drawn wagon decorated with Votes for Women symbols and filled with pro-suffrage literature, a sure way to attract publicity. Two weeks after the procession five New York suffragists, including Elizabeth Freeman, reported to the Bronx motion picture studio of the Thomas A. Edison Co. to make a talking picture known as a Kinetophone, which included a cylinder recording of one-minute speeches by each of the women. This film with synchronized sound was shown in vaudeville houses where it was "hooted, jeered and hissed" by audiences.

"Chasseur" is a term for light calvary: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chasseur

"Chasseur" is merely the French for "hunter": in a military context the nearest equivalent in British usage is "rifleman" as in "Rifle Brigade". It does also apply to a particular type of light cavalry, but these are clearly infantrymen. The German equivalent is jäger, and the photograph is probably of either a Feldjäger battalion or one of the four regiments of Tiroler Kaiserjäger of the Austro-Hungarian common army (k.u.k. Heer) around 1900.

William Gibbs McAdoo (1863–1941) was Woodrow Wilson's first Secretary of the Treasury, serving from 1913 until 1918. In 1914 he married Wilson's daughter, Eleanor. A native of Georgia and graduate of the University of Tennessee, he had a business career in New York prior to his service in Wilson's cabinet, and after leaving the administration he eventually moved to California where he was elected to the U.S. Senate, serving a single term beginning in 1933. Biographical Directory of the United States Congress. Wikipedia.
