In February, 1914, the 52-year-old Secretary McAdoo dazzled social butterflies of Atlanta when he bounced around the dance floor in a demonstration of the tango -- the new (and scandalously tactile) craze from Argentina. New York Times story, February 16, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9804E... Later in the year, McAdoo, a widower, married Eleanor Wilson, a daughter of President Woodrow Wilson, who was 26 years his junior. (They divorced in 1934.)

David Franklin Houston (1866–1940) served in the Wilson administration as Secretary of Agriculture (1913–1920) and as Secretary of the Treasury (1920–1921.) Prior to joining the Wilson cabinet, he had enjoyed a career in academia, and following his government service he entered the world of business.
Thanks!  We'll add the additional identification to the source data and reload the description.

The Houstons lived at 1808 New Hampshire Avenue in Washington, D.C. My mother often said she remembered the Easter Egg Hunts held on the White House lawn. After Wilson's Presidency was over, the family moved to 165 East 74th Street in New York City, where Mr. Houston served on the board of several companies, including U.S. Steel, AT&T, and several others. My mother, Helen Beall Houston,  attended The Brearley School there and enrolled in Bryn Mawr about 1929 but did not graduate. She moved to California in 1952.

Joseph Patrick Tumulty (1879–1954) was Private Secretary to President Woodrow Wilson, and as such a very influential person, but one about whom I've found very little on the Internet. He accounted for his own sometimes contradictory political views by calling himself a "conservative progressive." He was a close ally of Wilson's Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer, who went from being one of the most progressive members of the administration to being the instigator of the notorious Palmer Raids, in which upward of 10,000 suspected radicals were arrested under the Sedition Act, though many had no connection with any radical groups. (Dare to hope, prepare to be disappointed, I guess.) In contrast, in 1917 Tumulty wrote in a letter to Wilson warning of the dangers inherent in certain features pertaining to press censorship in the Espionage Bill of 1917, then being debated in Congress. In his letter, Tumulty said "The more completely the attempt to censor the press is killed, the better for the cause of freedom." He was a fascinating character whose weak Wikipedia biography deserves to be expanded. Tumulty's 1921 book, "Woodrow Wilson As I Knew Him" can be read online at Project Gutenberg, and can be downloaded as a .pdf from Google Books.

William Cox Redfield (1858–1932) served as a Democratic Representative from New York in the U.S. Congress, 1911–1913. He was the first U.S. Secretary of Commerce, installed as head the newly-created department by President Woodrow Wilson in 1913. He held the position until his resignation late in 1919. Josephus Daniels (1862–1948) was Secretary of the Navy during the Wilson administration. The North Carolina Democrat and long-time publisher of the Raleigh News & Observer also served as Ambassador to Mexico during the administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt. Daniels tended to be progressive in most matters other than race, and he remained a lifelong white supremacist. Wikipedia article. Josephus Daniels' family.

He's the cheerful looking fellow nearest the camera. Benjamin Ryan Tillman (1847-1918) was a U.S. Senator from South Carolina, from 1895 until his death in 1918. He gained the sobriquet "Pitchfork Ben" after threatening from the Senate floor to "...poke old [President] Grover [Cleveland] with a pitchfork...." Prior to his time in the Senate, he had been Governor of South Carolina from 1890 to 1894. During the period after the Civil War, he had been the leader of a paramilitary group called the Red Shirts, which had terrorized and sometimes murdered Republicans and African Americans. He was an advocate of lynching. There is a statue of him outside the South Carolina Statehouse. Fairly decent biographical sketch at Wikipedia.

porkfork6--good research on Burleson. I see many references on the Internet to a famous Burleson family from Texas. Your second link is to Laura Burgeson Negley, 1890-1913,and at first I thought that was her in the photo, but the age does not look right--she would have been 23 at this time. I think Mrs. Burleson is in the broad hat, and she looks older than 23. Good biographical information is here. I'll bet this is her mother--quoting from the above site: Laura's mother, Adele Lubbock Steiner Burleson (1863-1948), was a well-known author and playwright. Laura's father, Albert Sidney Burleson (1863-1937), represented Texas in the U.S. Congress from 1898-1912 and later was appointed Postmaster General by President Woodrow Wilson. See Wikipedia article, for instance, on Albert S. Burleson. However see comments on adjacent photo suggesting Mrs. R.C. Burleson for this woman--she was marshal of the parade. "Althea Taft" might be Althea Barr Taft, mentioned as being prominent in the Oklahoma Education Association circa 1914--Google Books (Altenbaugh, The Teacher's Voice, 1992). A little more research would probably identify all of these people. Photo was taken 3 March 1913 acc. to the caption--the day before Wilson's first inauguration.

The Mrs. Burleson in all these photos is Mrs. Richard Coke Burleson, whose husband was another member of that large Texas family. She was marshall of the parade. Edit: A complication arises: This Bain photo and this one both identify this Mrs. Burleson as "Mrs. R.S. Burleson." This could be an error, meant to read either "Mrs. R.C. Burleson (Mrs. Richard Coke Burleson) or "Mrs. A.S. Burleson (Mrs. Albert Sydney Burleson), or there was a third Mrs. Burleson hanging about in Washington in March of 1913. My money is on this being Mrs. R.C. Burleson, even though the photo of her in the parade shows her wearing a different outfit. Adele Burleson (Mrs. A.S.) would have been fifty years old in 1913, and while the woman in this photo looks a bit mature for twenty four (Mrs. R.C.'s age at the time), she certainly doesn't look fifty. An athletic horsewoman from San Saba, Texas, such as Mrs. R.C. Burleson, might have been expected to be a bit weathered at that age, in the days before sunblock was developed. Additional Edit: I've found an April, 1913, New York Times article about Adele Burleson, with a photo of her, and I'm now sure she was not the Mrs. Burleson in this photo. In addition, the Times article describes her as a small woman, "...who cannot possibly weigh over ninety-seven pounds...." If the woman in this photo weighs a mere ninety-seven pounds, I'll eat her enormous hat. Also, after saying that she supported women's suffrage, Mrs. A.S. went on to tell the Times "Not that I want to vote particularly, nor care to have my daughters overactive in politics, but I believe the granting of suffrage to women will make the world a fairer, squarer place for self-supporting women." These, I think, are not the sentiments of a woman who would march in a suffrage parade the day before the inauguration of the President who had named her husband Postmaster General.
Note, Wilson had in his cabinet a Postmaster General from Texas, Burleson, his nephew was married to the woman with the hat (who later murdered her husband's second wife).  see tag for Burleson.

My great aunt , K. Pearl Woodlief marched in this parade.  Being the only NC delegate, she carried the heavy NC flag throughout the parade.  She skipped work from the Durham, NC law firm where she was employed and when she telegraphed them on Monday morning, she was surprised to gain the support of the male lawyers of her firm.  She later worked with Alice Paul and others to establish a local chapter in NC and I still possess many of the letters she wrote to NC congressmen asking for their support.  She was born in Kittrell, NC in 1888.

I wonder if the Bain negative numbers could be used to put these pictures in sequential order. There is also this map of the order of marchers in the parade: www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/ppmsca.02946/

The Bain negative numbers may give a general idea of the sequence of images, but I don't think they can be used reliably to give the sequence of activities on a single day as in this case. Bain (or his staff) numbered these glass negatives after the fact, and we find that there are sometimes chronological anomalies, perhaps because a negative made much later was substituted for an earlier subject matter. (For a glimpse of operations in the Bain News Service office, see this image on the Library of Congress site: www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/ggbain.10071/. We're speculating that the boxes on the lower shelves may have held the glass negatives. The second-to-last number in the negative number string--e.g., 2505 in this case--may have been the number for a box of negatives.) Incidentally, we're coming up on the 100th anniversary of the march. Suffrage-centennial.org has posted plans for a re-enactment. There's an essay about the march (and the many materials in the Library of Congress that illuminate it) at: memory.loc.gov/ammem/awhhtml/aw01e/aw01e.html

Good question, chloe & ivan. I'll look into it, and have the tag removed if necessary. Thanks for catching it.

chloe & ivan: We'll leave the tag in, as we need to leave open the possibility that the words chosen are sometimes used interpretively, rather than factually. We all know that the horse is not the actual "Seabiscuit," who wasn't even born yet, and this setting is hardly a racetrack. But Seabiscuit was a symbol of hope for many, and perhaps our tagger was drawing on the hope he inspired, as Inex Milholland would have inspired to women of her time.

Since I was wondering what she died of, thought others might as well. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inez_Milholland Pernicious anemia (also known as Biermer's anaemia or Addison's anaemia or Addison-Biermer anaemia) is a form of megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B-12 (vitamin B12) deficiency, caused by impaired absorption of vitamin B-12[1] due to the absence of intrinsic factor[2] in the setting of atrophic gastritis, and more specifically of loss of gastric parietal cells. While the term "pernicious anemia" is sometimes also incorrectly used to indicate megaloblastic anemia due to any cause of vitamin B-12 deficiency, its proper usage refers to that caused by atrophic gastritis and parietal cell loss only. It is the most common result of adult vitamin B-12 deficiency.[3]

William Jennings Bryan (1860-1925) "For supporting Woodrow Wilson for the presidency in 1912, he was appointed as Secretary of State. Reverend Doctor Anna Howard Shaw (1847 - 1919) "A leader in the women's suffrage movement, Shaw was a master orator for social justice, and the first woman to be ordained by the Protestant Methodist Church. She was the first living American woman to be awarded the U.S. Distinguished Service Medal." Source: Anna Howard Shaw -- National Women's Hall of Fame You can read or download her autobiography from Google Books: The Story of a Pioneer
Thank you Elizabeth Thomsen.
Interesting.  She looks a bit masculine, but I do not mean that derogatorily.  It perhaps helped her back in those days as very few women received doctorates in any field.  Good for you, Dr. Shaw.
Where did she graduated from?

"In 1873, she entered Albion College, paying for her two years of education there by preaching and giving lectures on temperance. In 1876, she left Albion to attend Boston Theological Seminary. Upon graduation, in 1878, as the only woman in her class, she took charge of a church in East Dennis, Massachusetts, but the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church refused her application for ordination because she was a woman. It also took steps to revoke her preaching license. Finally, in 1880, Shaw convinced the Methodist Protestant Church to grant her ordination so she could administer the sacraments and continue her ministry in East Dennis. In addition to ministering at two churches, Shaw earned a medical degree from Boston University in 1886. However, she never practiced medicine." Source: Anna Howard Shaw -- National Women's Hall of Fame

"New Zealand women had become the first in the world to gain the right to vote in the national election. In 1894 South Australian Women were granted the right to vote followed by Western Australia in 1899, NSW in 1902 and finally Victoria in 1908. Australian women (except Aboriginal women) were enfranchised for the new Commonwealth Parliament in 1901. Women first voted in second Federal election in 1903. 2. However, women were not eligible for election to the State parliaments until the end of the First World War." From www.abc.net.au/ola/citizen/women/women-home-vote.htm

Mrs. Richard Coke Burleson was the former May Walker, born in San Saba, Texas, in 1889. Richard Burleson, son of Leigh Burleson, was also born in San Saba, in 1881. Two or three pages of a book called The Guns of Meeting Street by T. Felder Dorn concern the later lives of the Burlesons. In 1940, three years after a bitter divorce, May Burleson shot and killed her husband's second wife, the former Isabella Knowlton, in a Columbia, South Carolina hotel cafeteria. I don't have the book and only know what appears in a Google Books preview, which does not include the outcome of May's trial, though a line in the Bibliography indicates that the jury handed down a verdict of manslaughter with recommendation of mercy. Maybe I'll try to get my local library to buy a copy.
Great find on the murderous Mrs. Burleson!

This Wikipedia article about the First Balkan War has a helpful map, which if examined in full resolution, shows Vrania. It can be found on this map west of Sophia (Bulgaria), on the border between Serbia and Macedonia:: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Balkan_War Looks like it is now called Vranje and is in southern region of Serbia. Here is Wikpedia article about it: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vranje Newspaper account in Internet: (Oct 18, 1912) "The Turkish troops attacked the Ser vian outposts near VRANIA. a customs examination station on the line to Salonica and crossed into Servian territory." In other accounts Vrania is mentioned as being on the rail line between Nish and Salonica. Salonica is currently called Thessaloniki (population 1million), in Greece: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thessaloniki Here is a article on Nish a city in Serbia with 250K inhabitants. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nish Vrania is also described as being on the railway between Nish and Skopie (Skopje) in Macedonia.

The New York Times archive lets us down on this one. There's a 175 word article dated February 20, 1913, with the headline "LEAGUE ISLAND MARINES OFF.; 1,300 Sail Early This Morning -- 8-Inch Shells Aboard." Unfortunately, the .pdf of the complete article is blank except for the fragment "....they had been ordered to rush the work. The shells are intended for use on the warships." A Marine Corps Historical Reference Pamphlet (online here) says, in the second paragraph of part 3, Section I:
"The final one of these temporary '2d Regiment' organizations to be formed was designated as the 2d Regiment, 2d Provisional Brigade on 19 February 1913 at Philadelphia. Headed by Colonel Joseph H. Pendleton, the regiment was originally intended for duty in Mexico as part of an expeditionary brigade. Instead, it was sent to Guantanamo Bay and held in readiness for emergency duties, while undergoing intensive training. On 1 May, this unit was redesignated 2d Regiment, Expeditionary Force, USMC. As such, it remained in Cuba until the latter part of the month, when it boarded the PRAIRIE for the United States, arriving at Philadelphia on 1 June, when it was dissolved."
It seems a reasonable surmise that the Marines in these photos, and those who were the subject of the Times article, might have been this regiment.

From this photo it's pretty obvious that the MEADE was designed as a passenger ship, not a naval vessel. There were in fact two destroyers called MEADE, but the first of these wasn't commissioned until 1919. After searching the Internet, I've found a bit of information about the ship in these photos. This U.S. Army transport ship was built in 1874 for the Inman line, originally named the CITY OF BERLIN, and renamed BERLIN when sold to the American Line in 1893. In 1898 she was purchased by the U.S. government and renamed MEADE, according to this page at Norway-Heritage, which also says the ship was scrapped in 1921. However, this page at the Vallejo Gallery website features a painting of the MEADE, and the accompanying text says that she was listed as an Army transport ship until 1921, and was sold to a San Francisco doctor in 1934. This page also describes the ship as a steam screw yacht of 5641 tons, with a length of 488.6', a beam of 44.2', and a draught of 34.9'. Vallejo Gallery also displays this ca.1910 photo of the MEADE running on San Francisco Bay, with inset portraits of the ship's officers.

After a false start (see my comment on this photo of Young Britt and Kid Williams), I've been able to identify both of the boxers in this photo, thanks to the book "Baltimore's Boxing Legacy" by Thomas Schaif (Mount Pleasant, S.C.: Arcadia Publishing, 2003.) On page 7 it says:
"On Bond Street, just around the corner from Fleet, stands the building where Johnny Gutenko became Kid Williams. In a small room behind a confectionery store—run by Tom the Greek—Williams learned to box with the help of local boxer Young Britt."
This identifies the Young Britt in this photo as the bantamweight born in 1890 whose real name was Henry Treffinger (bout list at BoxRec.) Kid Williams (1893-1963) was born John Gutenko in Copenhagen, Denmark. In his long ring career he fought more than 200 bouts, winning 156 of them, and held the title of Bantamweight Champion of the World from 1914 to 1917 (bout list at BoxRec.)

Looking at other photos of Kid Williams (I haven't found any non-LOC photos of Young Britt), I'm wondering if Bain got the identities switched. Look at these photos of Kid Williams from BoxRec and from Cyber Boxing Zone Encyclopedia. See the other LOC photo I linked to in my comment above, too, which shows both boxers from their other side. To my eye, the photos of Williams from the other sites both more closely resemble the blond on the right in this photo and the left in the other Bain photo than they do the darker fellow identified in the Bain captions as Williams. There are also photos of Williams on page 8 and page 53 of the Thomas Schaif book I cite in my previous comment. They are definitely the same blond guy on the BoxRec and Cyber Boxing pages, so any error is not theirs. I'm pretty sure Bain's captioner got this wrong. Anybody else see the resemblances I do?

whyaduck: Thanks for all of your research on these boxers. We'll add the information to our source catalog. We're not sure about whether the identities are switched or not so will probably hold off on making a note about that.

I've found a small photograph of Henry Treffinger, aka Young Britt, on this page. It convinces me that whoever put the caption onto these negatives reversed the identities. Note that the photos from the other sites show that Kid Williams parted his (light) hair on the right, and Young Britt parted his (dark) hair on the left. Other features (forehead height, nose shape, jawline, ear size and shape) strongly indicate a reversal as well.

text is legible on the monument and it refers to Samuel Pierpont Langley, Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. Langley was a pioneer in aviation. Here is article about him from Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Langley May 7, 1913] Langley Memorial Unveiled at Smithsonian Institution. SCIENTISTS EULOGIZE HIM AG Bell Presents Medals to Glenn Curtiss and Gustave Eiffel." French Ambassador Receives Gift in Be- half of Absent Countryman -- Struggles of "Father of Modern Aviation," Said to Have Died of Broken Heart. ... From HONOR AIR PIONEER - Washington Post ($$)

Langley's airplanes didn't work, and after repeated failures he was upstaged in December, 1903, by the Wright Brothers. But because of its allegiance to Secretary Langley, the Smithsonian Institution refused for years to recognize the Wright Brothers' primacy over Langley, who had desperately wanted to go down in history as the first to make a powered flight. Orville Wright donated his original biplane to a British museum, and the Smithsonian didn't get it until after WWII, when they apologized to Wright for the snub.

John Flanagan (1865-1952), the designer of this plaque and numerous others, also came up with the design of the 1932 George Washington memorial (bicentennial) quarter.

The Washington Post has an article about this fascinating 1912 episode called the Battle of Monticello, here is the link: www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A24693-2001Nov13?langua... The lady on the right, Maud Littleton, was married to a Congressman, Martin W. Littleton of New York. She was a huge fan of Thomas Jefferson and she was invited to dinner at Monticello by another congressman, who just happened to privately own the house, which he had inherited. Mrs. Littleton came away from the dinner charged with a passion to see that Monticello would be owned by the Nation, rather than an individual. So began her quest which was to run into many roadblocks, which just made her more determined. Her nemesis was the owner of Monticello, another Congressman from NY, by the name of Jefferson Levy. His being Jewish seems to have caused some backlash against his family being the owner of Monticello (or maybe it was that he was from New York). Anyway, Mrs. Littleton was a woman who was thought by some to be quot;meddling" in national politics and that may have stimulated opposition to her quest. It is a great story. Here is a NYTimes article. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B07E0DD1F3CE6... Congressman Littleton's bio: bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=L000359 Her political ally and the other man in the picture is evidently Congressman Robert Lee Henry, Chairman of the Rules Committee. Here is a lead from a news story: NO MONTICELLO PURCHASE.; House Refuses to Consider It -- Jefferson Descendant Condemns Movement. December 10, 1912, Tuesday WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- By a vote of 141 to 101, the House of Representatives to-day refused to adopt a special rule brought in by Chairman Henry of the Rules Committee providing for immediate consideration of the Senate concurrent resolution calling for the creation of a joint Congressional committee to consider the wisdom and cost of acquiring Monticello, the home of Thomas Jefferson, by the Federal Government. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9404E3DB1E3AE633A... Here is fragment of bio of Congressman Henry: (from Congressional Biographic Resource). HENRY, Robert Lee, (great-great-great-grandson of Patrick Henry), a Representative from Texas. Elected as a Democrat to the Fifty-fifth and to the nine succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1897-March 3, 1917); chairman, Committee on Rules (Sixty-second through Sixty-fourth Congresses); was not a candidate for renomination in 1916, but was an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator; engaged in the practice of law in Waco, Tex.; again an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in 1922 and 1928; moved to Houston, Tex., in 1923 and resumed the practice of his profession; died in Houston, Tex., July 9, 1931, from a gunshot wound; interment in Rose Hill Cemetery, Texarkana, Tex. NYTimes reported it as suicide: SUICIDE ENDS CAREER OF R.L. HENRY IN TEXAS; Ex-Member of Congress, Long a Political Figure, Was Ill and Had Met Reverses. July 10, 1931, Friday HOUSTON Texas, July 9.--Worried over recent financial reverses and suffering from ill health, Robert Lee Henry, 67 years old, a member of Congress from Texas for twenty years, ended his life with a pistol shot at his residence here early this morning. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0A15F83C591B72...

Odds are that this is not the Republican Convention. In 1912, both the Republican and Bull Moose (Progressive Party) conventions were held at the same Chicago Convention Hall. Both conventions had delegates from various states. Roosevelt attended both conventions, but he was humiliated at the GOP gathering and lionized later at the Bull Moose conclave. Although women did not yet have the vote, they were included in the councils of the Progressive Party. The presence of several women delegates in this photo makes it likely that this is the "Bull Moose" convention.

There is a description of this photo--NY Times, 22 December 1912--(link)The Attitude of Austria in the Eastern Question--from the OCR on Google, I guess The Central Figure (Without a Hat) is Consul Kirchknopf of New York, Hilski Pasha ... and Russian Ambassador at Constantiple de Giers, (with Derby Hat Below de Giers and to the right is another figure--looks like a Russian in a naval uniform. He is not identified in the article that I see. The article is quite lengthy--gives a lot of context. Wikipedia article on Nicholas de Giers (1820-1895) identifies his son: His son Mikhail Nikolayevich von Giers acted as last Imperial Russian Ambassador in Constantinople until the beginning of World War I in 1914. So the guy in the derby hat is Mikhail Nikolayevich von Giers--I don't see any biographical information on him, in a quick search, but this is a start. Edit: More on Kirchknopf, Hilmi Pacha. A New York Times article from 19 September 1912 (link) mentions briefly, "Acting Consul-General Kirchknopf", apparently of the Austro-Hungarian embassy in New York. "Hilmi Pacha" would appear to be Hüseyin Hilmi Pasha, an Ottoman diplomat. So this appears to be a diplomatic meeting of Turks, Russians, and Austro-Hungarians, the date apparently circa September, 1912. Location is New York , presumably.

(former judge) John W. Westcott planned to run for Senate (from New Jersey) in 1912, with apparent backing of newly elected NJ Gov Woodrow Wilson, according to NYTimes articles from 1912. This was before the Constitution was amended to provide for direct election of Senators, and at that time the State legislature picked the Senators. There was some political intrigue involving former NJ Sen. Smith a "boss" who was trying to return to the Senate by cashing in his political IOUs. Wilson opposed Smith (who had supported Wilson) as an early sign of Wilson's agenda of reform and sweeping out bosses, even Dem bosses. Ultimately James Martine got the Dem nomination and was elected Senator from NJ instead of either Smith or Westcott. June 28, 1912, Judge Westcott gives a rousing speech in nominating Woodrow Wilson for President at the Democratic convention in Baltimore. Westcott shows up as being Attorney General for New Jersey and then trying again to run for Senate to replace Sen Martine. He did not get the Dem nomination and then Martine was defeated by Republican Freylinghuysen in 1916
His name is properly spelled Wescott, not Westcott. www.nj.gov/lps/oag/ag_1914-1919_wescott_bio.htm
bgzimmer: thanks for spotting the spelling error. We'll fix this and then reload the description.

John Wesley Wescott (February 20, 1849 – June 11, 1927) was an American lawyer and jurist who served as Attorney General of New Jersey from 1914 to 1919. He had the distinction of making the nominating speech for Woodrow Wilson at the Democratic National Convention in both 1912 and 1916. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Wescott

Platt Adams (b.1885), his brother Ben Adams (b.1890), and Jim Duncan (b.1887) were American track & field athletes who competed in the 1912 Olympic games in Stockholm. Platt Adams won the silver medal in the standing long jump and the gold medal in the standing high jump: www.databaseolympics.com/players/playerpage.htm?ilkid=ADA... Ben Adams won the bronze medal in standing long jump and the silver medal in standing high jump: www.databaseolympics.com/players/playerpage.htm?ilkid=ADA... Olympics.com Jim Duncan won the bronze medal in the discus throw: www.databaseolympics.com/players/playerpage.htm?ilkid=DUN...; This photo looks as though it was taken on board a ship. It might have been taken on the occasion of the team's departure for Europe. The American Olympic team sailed for Stockholm on June 14, 1912, on board the USS Finland, which had been chartered for the voyage by the American Olympic Committee: en.wikipedia.org/wiki?title=USS_Finland

"Jimmy Esson from Aberdeen, was acclaimed as World Heavyweight Champion when he won the Lonsdale Challenge Cup and the National Sporting Club’s tournament in the Alhambra in London in 1908."

This is definitely NOT a 110m race, since no such race was ever contested at an Olympics without hurdles. Running in lanes through a curve suggests either a 200m or 400m, but this is most likely the 400m. The background is where the present day finish line is (and I believe where it was in 1912 as well), and the relatively even stagger among the runners again suggests that this just after the start of the 400. There are five runners in the field. Assuming that this is the final, that also points to the 400 since there were five runners in the 400m final, and six in the 200m. From the results of the 400m final, the runners, from right (lane 1) to left (lane 5): 1. Ted Meredith (USA) 2. Hanns Braun (GER) 3. Charles Reidpath (USA) 4. Carroll Haff (USA) 5. Edward Lindberg (USA) The uniforms that are clearly visible match that lineup. Edited to add source: bottom of page 64, Olympic Track & Field statistics book, published by IAAF (International governing body for T&F). Lanes are in parentheses next to order of finish. www.iaaf.org/mm/document/competitions/competition/p1-181_... -- Seen on your photo stream. (?)
#5 is Francisco Ignacio Madero, President of Mexico 1911-1913. The caption says "F. I. Madero" and the photo is a match for the one in the Wikipedia article.

#3 in the photograph is Venustiano Carranza. 

I haven't heard of the Carrenas name in Mexico, unless it could be Carreñas. Yet, when I saw who the person was, no doubt, his beard and eyeglasses says it all... he is Venustiano Carranza. 

When president Madero (#5 in the photograph) and Pino Suarez are assasinated by Huerta (not in the picture), Venustiano Carranza declares war against Huerta on the inconstitutionality of the coup d'etat. His army was known as the Carrancistas or the Ejercito Constitucionalista (Constitutionalist Army). He also became president but was also assasinated.

This has been described in The New York Times as Miss Marjorie Smylie and her dog "Bo Peep of Devonshire". Bo Peep was shown at the Toy Spaniel Club of America's ninth annual exhibition, held on December 1, 1911, at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York City. Bo Beep was also shown at the Pekingese Club of America's show, December 1, 1913, at the Plaza Hotel in New York City. No reference was made to what is presumed to be the other dog in the photograph – "Sweet Joan of Minoro" – which may be the exception proving the rule that "every dog has their day" ;-)   "Minoro" may also be a typo. Marjorie Smylie is the daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Griffen (nèe Julia Ely) and her first husband, Major Charles Albert Smylie.   Mrs. Griffen later divorced Benjamin Griffen after seven years of marriage.

This is actually the wife of NY Gov William Sulzer, (with a z) who was impeached in 1913 (his first year in office). Mrs. Sulzer apparently tried to take some of the heat off of him during his trial by saying that she forged his name, and SHE was the one who used campaign contributions to speculate in the stock market. But her "confession" was thought to be bogus in the ensuing investigation: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Sulzer query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F05E2DA163DE633A... This picture appeared in the NYTimes on Jan 3, 1913 in a long article about Gov. Sulzer's first day in office. It has a caption about Mrs. Sulzer accepting the first parcel post package sent to Albany via Parcel Post. Maybe this is campaign money in the parcel? query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9403E0DA123BE633A... READY WITH VOTES TO IMPEACH HIM, ASSEMBLY DEBATING SULZER AT 3:30 A.M. GOVERNOR'S WIFE WOULD TAKE BLAME; New Aspect Cast Upon Charges by a Strange "Confession." (8/13/1913) But she did not have great luck with the parcel post either, see below. Here is article from Feb 7, 1913: "One of the evening papers printed an Albany dispatch recently to the effect that Mrs. William Sulzer, wife of our present Governor, has failed to receive a number of gifts sent to her by admirers through the parcel post. According to the news item, Mrs. Sulzer intends to bring the matter to the attention of the Post Office Department.
Was it his punishment that Mrs. Sulzer had to wear that hat? (:

This appears to be a "banana boat", or refrigerated fruit transport, belonging to the United Fruit Company. The funnel colors would have been black on top, a red band with white diamond in the middle, and buff colored on the bottom. 

I believe the name of the ship is actually the "Santa Marta", not the Santa Maria. Santa Marta is a coastal town in Colombia and was a place of export for bananas. It's definitely pictured in New York, because you can see the Brooklyn Bridge in the background. These ships were painted white to keep the cargo cooler, and they also carried some passengers.

More on Santa Marta, from "Going Bananas: 100 Years of American Fruit Ships in the Caribbean" by Mark H. Goldberg, ISBN 1879180018:

Santa Marta, built 1909, 5,013 tons displacement, 392' long, 50' beam, 13 knots speed, scrapped in Baltimore 1948, 12 sister ships. On page 355 of the book, there is a photo of her at the same East River pier, from a different angle.

I think this must be an early photo of mystery writer Frances Noyes Hart. The Noyes family owned the Washington Star, so her photo showing up in a newspaper even before she published any of her books would not be surprising.
In regard to captainslack's comment above: the LOC photo linked there does not depict Frances Noyes, but dancer Florence Fleming Noyes.

Thanks for pointing out potential connections to other Library of Congress photographs -- and potential identity confusions! If you want to see even more of the story on identity confusions (not Florence Noyes and not Lady Liberty according to information researchers gave us), see the image and revised title in the Prints and Photographs Online Catalog: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ppmsc.00032

The photo of Hedwig Reicher in costume as Columbia is all over the Internet, identified as Florence F. Noyes as Liberty. Everybody must be relying on the misleading Bain caption. The LOC does have a decent photo of Florence Fleming Noyes, but the photo with Hedwig Reichert isn't big enough, even in its TIFF version, to be able to make a comparison between the picture of Ms. Noyes and the background figures in the Reichert photo to determine if she is among them. The LOC also has another photo of Frances Noyes, but it is in the Arnold Genthe collection which has not been made available online in large versions. From the thumbnail (use the terms "Noyes, Miss" on the Prints & Photographs search page), it appears to be the same woman at the wheel of the car in the photo above, though somewhat gussied up. It occurs to me that, since Frances Noyes served as an ambulance driver during WWI (her first published book was about her war experiences- available for download in several formats here at the Internet Archive), the photo above may depict her at about that time- perhaps 1917-1918. The right-hand-drive car suggests that the photograph might have been taken in England.
The buildings in the background don't look English at all.

Frances Noyes Hart (1890-1943) was an American writer whose short stories were published in Scribner's magazine, the Saturday Evening Post, the Ladies' Home Journal. Her father was the head of the Associated Press. She married Edward H. Hart in 1921. If this image is from 1913, she would have been 23 years old when she embarked on a tour of the world with Martha Bowers and Thomas W. Bowers. It was covered in the Washington Post. The Bowers are most likely the passengers in the car. I started a Wikipedia entry on her: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frances_Noyes_Hart And one on her father: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Brett_Noyes

Michel Marcel Navratil, Jr. (June 12, 1908 – January 30, 2001), was one of the last survivors of the sinking of the RMS Titanic on April 15, 1912. Michel, along with his brother, Edmond Navratil (1910-1953), were known as the Titanic Orphans, having been the only children rescued without a parent or guardian. He was the last male survivor of the Titanic. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michel_Marcel_Navratil

This photo most likely dates from 1911 or soon after. Though the legislature of California passed a bill granting women the vote as early as 1893, it was vetoed by Governor Henry Markham. In 1896, a  referendum  to legalize woman suffrage in the state failed. It was not until the election of October, 1911, that another referendum passed by a large margin, and California's women voted for the first time later that year.

This photograph has been published numerous times. Robert D Ballard, in "The Discovery of the Titanic" credits it to the Walter Lord Collection and captions it "Boat no 14, towing collapsible D, approaches the Carpathia".

Walter Lord's book, "A Night to Remember" publishes a wider angle view from the same shot, captioned "Fifth Officer Lowe has by now lowered the sail on No 14 and is rowing up to the Carpathia. He can be seen standing in the stern at the tiller. Behind him he tows Collapsible D, which he found wallowing in the sea an hour earlier." This is credited "by courtesy of Mrs Louis M Ogden".

Mrs Ogden was a passenger aboard Carpathia.

The title of the ship was SS Carpathia (steam ship) as compared with RMS Titanic (Royal Mail Ship). The story that the SS Carpathia was given the title of RMS some time well after the rescue operation is very sketchy. Ship enthusiasts generally get quite annoyed when the proper designations are left off or listed incorrectly.

This is interesting, because at the moment we must assume that Bryan is standing at the podium in the centre background stage.  Yet, many people closer tot he camera are looking to the right rear of the camera.  Possibly more than one speaker's podium at this event.

Bain's photo bears the date April 20, 1912. The venue is the "cottage" in New York City's Union Square. A story in The New York Times on the following day reported that Bryan had addressed a large crowd of Columbia University students at Horace Mann Auditorium. The New York Times, April 21, 1912: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E0DEEDD1E3CE6... Bryan was in New York City as a delegate to the "Men in Religion Forward Convention," and stayed at the Hotel Astor, according to an item in The New York Times, April 22, 1912: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E01EFDA1F31E2...

A new Bain/LOC Flickr posting (November 12, 2010) of a Suffragette rally on May 2, 1914, gives a better view of the background structure and identifies this scene as Union Square, New York City:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5169603438/]

Born into New York society, Constance Whitney Warren (1888-1948) became a sculptor specializing in Western American subjects. Count Guy De Lasteyrie was a descendant of the Marquis de Lafayette. Their engagement was announced in October, 1912. Here's the New York Times account of their wedding, in December, 1912. In 1925, one of Warren's best-known works, a life-sized equestrian sculpture called The Texas Cowboy, was installed on the grounds of the state capitol building in Austin. After a decade or so of success as an artist, during which time she completed about 100 works, Constance Warren suffered a mental breakdown and was committed to an institution, where she remained for the final 18 years of her life. I've been unable to find out if the marriage of Constance Warren and the Comte produced children, or what became of Guy De Lasteyrie. A brief biography of Constance Warren begins on this web page maintained by the University of North Texas.

Slight correction. James W. was not a founder of the conservation movement, except indirectly. He was the father of Amos, Antoinette, and Amos Pinchot. Gifford was encouraged by his father to study forestry, so Gifford, who went on to found the Forest Service in 1905, credited his father with being the "Father of Forestry." But James was a wealthy New York businessman, not a lumber baron. The Pinchot family funded the establishment of the Yale School of Forestry in 1900, and James probably contributed the bulk of the initial $150,000 and possibly the eventual $300,000. Gifford and others were the founders of the Conservation Movement during TR's presidency. In 1912, Amos and Gifford were major supporters of TR's third-party run for the presidency.

The Lusitania was the sister ship of the Mauritania. They were practically identical but the Lusitania had simple lids to the top of her ventilator shafts (clearly visible in this picture) whilst the Mauritania had scoops making for easy identification of the two great sisters of the sea.

Throughout the period from 1907 to the outset of World War 1 the two sisters vied for the Blue Riband with the Mauritania ultimately proving the very marginally faster.
They were a bit more like step sisters, The Aquitania was 104 feet longer and 10 feet wider and so was able to have larger rooms.

Same location as this photo, the National Cloak & Suit Company building. According to the NYT, the National Cloak and Suit Company occupied "the entire west side of the block on Seventh Avenue between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Street" in New York City. A look at Google Maps' Street View confirms that it's this location, 250 Seventh Avenue, currently a Whole Foods store. There is also an October 10, 1912 story about city-wide fire drill exercises the previous day, one of which took place at the building, so this picture could have been taken on October 9, 1912, unless there other fire drills of this type taken in other years.

Oscar Solomon Straus - Jewish statesman and diplomat to the Middle East, influential in the late 1880s to 1890s as US Minister in Turkey. Later U.S. Sec. of Commerce & Labor in 1900s under President Theodore "Teddy" Roosevelt - Served one year again in Turkey, as Ambassador, under President Taft. Wrote his autobiography in 1922, "Under Four Administrations: From Cleveland to Taft." His older brother, Isidor Straus and his wife were among the victims in the sinking of the Titanic in 1912.

Oscar Solomon Straus - Jewish statesman and diplomat to the Middle East, influential in the late 1880s to 1890s as US Minister in Turkey.  Later U.S. Sec. of Commerce & Labor in 1900s under President Theodore "Teddy" Roosevelt -  Served one year again in Turkey, as Ambassador, under President Taft.  Wrote his autobiography in 1922, "Under Four Administrations: From Cleveland to Taft."   His older brother, Isidor Straus and his wife were among the victims in the sinking of the Titanic in 1912.

Judge William H. Moore (b.1848) was a Chicago attorney, capitalist, and promoter who put together a number of business combines in the late 19th-early 20th centuries, including the National Biscuit Company. In later years he lived in New York, and though he was long known for his fine stable of horses, it was during this time that his equine exploits became common fodder for the newspapers. The New York Times archives hold many articles about the judge and his horses from about 1901 into the 1910s. I've no idea from which of of those occasions this photo dates, but it might depict the team with which Judge Moore won the four-in-hand competition at the 1903 Brooklyn horse show, as related in this May 7, 1903 Times article.

This photo is from the Bain News Agency's 1912 photostream, although of course it could have been taken earlier. Bain probably circulated the photo to his subscribers to accompany news reports that Judge Moore had spent two weeks of June, 1912, in England, where his horses competed in the Olympia Horse Show in London, winning the Gold Challenge Cup for the Coaching Marathon (for the second year in a row) and ten other blue ribbon first prizes, as well as numerous lesser awards. Here's the story from the New York Times, June 30, 1912: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=990CE5D81E3CE6...

William Henry Moore (1848 - January 11, 1923) was an attorney and financier. He organized and promoted or sat as a director for several steel companies that were merged with among others the Carnegie Steel Company to create United States Steel. He and his brother Hobart helped create the Diamond Match Company, National Biscuit Company, First National Bank, the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, the American Can Company, the Lehigh Valley Railroad, the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, the Continental Fire Insurance Company, the Western Union Telegraph Company, the American Cotton Oil Company, and Bankers Trust. Moore was an avid and expert horsemen en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Henry_%22Judge%22_Moore

A November 24, 1913, photo of boxer Charles Morris shows another chamber in this suite, with the identical wallpaper: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4605956627/] @undeadsinatra: In the 19th century, a cult of the Apache was active in the French underworld, especially in Paris. They took their name from the Apache Indians of North America, and were famous for their costumes, wearing flashy shirts with horizontal stripes. Charles Ledoux was a gritty, hard-hitting French bantamweight who mixed it up with many of the best fighters in his weight range during a long boxing career (1909-1925)—such greats as Joe Bowker, Johnny Buff, Joe Burman, Eddie Campi, Johnny Curtin, Kid Francis, Danny Kramer, Andre Routis, Sid Smith, Digger Stanley, and Hall of Famers Johnny Coulon, Eugene Criqui, Jim Driscoll, Joe Lynch, Kid Williams and the legendary Pete Herman. He was at one time recognized by London's National Sporting Club as the world bantamweight champion (Coulon had wider recognition). In 1913, at the age of 20, Ledoux lost a decision to Campi for the vacant bantamweight title of the old IBU and less than a month later he was beaten by Williams, who claimed the world title; Williams would go on to beat Campi and Coulon as well to cement his claim. Ledoux would have to wait a long time for another shot at the bantamweight title. At the age of 32 and nearing the end of his years in the ring, Ledoux challenged world champion Abe Goldstein and lost a 15-round decision. Less than a year later he hung up his gloves for good. Ledoux died in 1967 at the age of 74.

Attending such a trials may have been her cup of tea. She had been active in the 1911 strike, monitoring trials, and legislative aftermath of a tragic fire in a sweatshop (the Triangle Shirtwaist fire -- see www.gale.cengage.com/free_resources/whm/trials/triangle.htm).

Sam Schepps was a witness in the Becker case according to news reports. The Becker Case was the murder of a gambler, Rosenthal, by gangsters at behest of policeman Charles Becker. Schepps was thought to be the "paymaster" of the murderers, giving them the $100 bills that enabled them to get out of town. Here is article about his arrest: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9403E1DD1F3CE6... Here is citation about Becker en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Becker

There are many other photographs relating to the Becker case strewn throughout the LOC Bain Collection set - many of them having the words "Gunmen trial" included in the original caption. This makes me wonder if the photograph of "Mrs. Belmont at Gunmen's trial" here: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2496407997/ was also taken at that particular trial.

Ishbel Marjoribanks, Marchioness of Aberdeen, wife of the Governor General of Canada - Victorian society - gentry - Made her coming out at a party presided by Queen Victoria - resided West End London - First President NCWC, 1890s (National Council of Women in Canada) - reputedly sold her own jewels to raise charity funds - founded May Court Convalescent Home in Ottawa, Canada - Author of a travel book "Through Canada with a Kodak" possibly containing photographs of Canada made with early Kodak camera. A brother, Edward Majoribanks, Second Baron of Tweedmouth, was married to Lady Fanny Spencer-Churchill, Winston Churchill's aunt and a daughter of the Duke of Marlborough See: www.geocities.com/daniellla.geo/ishbel.html See also: www.scotclans.com/scottish_clans/clans/marjoribanks/peopl...

I wonder if it could be this Louise Jorgensen, said to be a dancer(?) in Oakland, CA? "For almost 70 years, from 1919 until the pageant's farewell performance in 1987, a one-woman powerhouse, Louise Jorgensen, transformed the Cadigans and thousands of other Oakland schoolchildren into dancing toys and ballerinas for two performances during the first weekend of December."
Her dress and moccasins are beautiful. Why is she wearing them? Who is she?

Yes, absolutely certain this is Louise Jorgensen of Oakland.  Knew her very very well and recognized her immediately in this photo.  She studied many types of dance throughout her career, so this costume was most likely for some type of performance.  She was primarily a ballet dancer and teacher, and was most noted as director of Oakland's Children's Christmas Pageant 1919-1987.

Miss Jorgensen was my ballet instructor when i was a child.  I took classes with her at First Presbyterian Church in Oakland Ca. from 1st grade until 5th grade.  She was an amazing dancer & a wonderful teacher.  I can remember dancing the "Flight of the Bumblebees"...weaving the Maypole...  and  dancing every year in the Oakland Christmas Pageant. I have been searching for footage online for years of the Oakland Children's Christmas Pageant.  I was a student of hers in the 70's & 80's every Wed. at the First Presbyterian Church in Oakland Ca.  Memories of Doll Day, The Maypole, Fairyland, Ms. Jorgensen's Castanets, and the beloved Christmas Pageant.  I started in the pageant as Fairy at 3 1/2 yrs old and danced in it every year til the last year 1987.  One year I got to be the doll that came out of the large pink box and got carried around the arena on Santa's shoulder.  A favorite moment of the pageant would be the roar of the crowd when that majestic large Christmas tree would light up during the Ornaments Dance....wait.. the best moment of the pageant was The spirit of Christmas when Ms. Jorgensen would dance with the few special little fairy dancers and then the large doors would open to reveal hundreds of darling little skipping fairies...I'm tearing up right now just thinking about it. Beautiful Memories for all those who experienced the joy of Ms. Jorgensen and her beloved pageant. Alanda D. in Antioch

Bartlett mentions a "young English photographer named Gordon", I wonder if he could have been the one to take this photo? Of course it seems that war was well-covered, I also see that the American photojournalist Jimmy Hare covered it. Seems like the place and date of this photo are relatively well-established, between 30 October and 3 November 1912, near Sakizkoy, Turkey. A sad tale of misery--the Balkan Wars--rather overshadowed in history by the infinitely more horrible World War I to come in just two years.

Another LOC photo here shows the same scene from further back, captioned "Paul Sorg, E. Fownes driving". This article from the 24 April 1903 NY Times mentions an incident where some property of "Paul A. Sorg" young millionaire of Middletown Ohio, was seized by a Sheriff just before Sorg was about to leave for Europe. An English "whip" (coach driver?) named Charles A. Fownes is also mentioned. There is a famous Paul John Sorg, but he was born in 1840 died in 1902. That appears to have been the father of Paul A. Sorg, listed in the article as 1878-1913--see Middletown Library, gives some family history: Paul Arthur Sorg was the son of Paul J. and Susan Jennie Sorg. His family was very well off financially and Paul A. Sorg was placed in charge of the paper concerns that the family owned...spent much time in New York State and raised excellent horses Here is a photo of Paul Arthur Sorg--that looks like it could be the person in the photo here--though it looks like he grew a mustache. Paul Arthur Sorg died 4 (?) May 1913 in New York, aged 34, according to the NY Times obituary from 6 May 1913. Seems pretty clear "Sorg" is Paul Arthur Sorg (circa 1878-1913). He appears to be examining the coach, could this have been the incident described in the NY Times article?

Jim Savage was a New Jersey boxer active in the ring from at least 1908 until at least 1917. Later he was a referee at Madison Square Garden, and a trainer. Thumbnail biography from The Cyber Boxing Zone.

Jim Savage was a professional heavy weight boxer from 1898 to 1917.  He fought over 120 fights around the world.   He also did two silent films.  Early in his career he sparred with Bob Fitzsimmons because Bob liked the speed of Jim and it was good for Bob in his later years. Fitzsimmonas became Jim's mentor and Jim lived with Fitzsimmons for a while. After his retirement from the ring he became the Athletic Director for the Motion Picture Club in NYC as well as a referee at Madision Square Garden (most notable) and other Athletic clubs in NY and NJ.   During his retirement he became the personal trainer and bodyguard for the tin can magnate, Daniel G. Reid.  Jim traveled with Reid for many years.  Jim Savage died in 1946 in Orange, N.J.

Found a reference to Peter Gotz in the following of the history of commonwealth wrestling:

In 1904 the USA held the Olympic Games in St. Louis and had included wrestling but only Free-style. The problems of distance, expense and the lack of Greco-Roman meant that no European wrestlers travelled to the USA, so the competition was in effect a re-run of the American Championships.

The decisive year for Catch-as-catch-can in the drive to establish it as a world sport was1908; three major events took place that year in London, which confirmed the sport’s international status. The Alhambra Tournament which finished on February 1st, the Hengler’s Circus Tournament, which commenced in May 6th and lasted eight weeks and a couple of weeks later the Olympic Games.

The National Sporting Club, England’s most influential sporting body, had decided to put some order into the often farcical newspaper claims of ‘world’ or ‘British’ or ‘Empire’ champion by organising a strictly enforced and legitimate professional World Championship in three weight categories. Lord Lonsdale the fifth Earl of Lonsdale (1857/1944) was the President of the National Sporting Club and all the officials in the tournament were amateur; among them was A.H. Sutherland, Chairman of the National Amateur Wrestling Association. The event was to be held annually in the Alhambra Theatre in London and was the most important professional tournament in the drive to establish legitimate international Catch-as-catch-can championships, in the face of European pressure for Greco-Roman only. It was publicised as widely as the technology of the period would permit; Hackenschmidt, Yokio Tani (1881/1950) of Japan, Cherpillod of Switzerland and several other famous stars were invited but declined; basically because defeat would affect their lucrative music hall contracts.

As always happens in big tournaments there were some unexpected results, Peter Gotz (1887/1944) of Germany failed to make the weight at lightweight but placed second in the middleweights. Yamato Maida (1874/1944) from Hirosaki City in Japan, the best of the Japanese in Europe, and who was the man most responsible for the world wide spread of Judo was easily beaten by Henry Irslinger of Austria in the first round of the middleweight class. Despite his defeat he entered the heavyweight class and placed 2nd. This was the first legitimate international championship tournament in Catch-as-catch-can; wrestlers from eight countries competed, England, Scotland, Ireland, Austria, Germany, Italy, Switzerland and Japan

I am proud to say Peter Gotz was my Great Grandfather! My father was proud to have him as his Grandfather and my Grandfather, his son, was proud of him as well!  It is only the folly of youth and inexperience of life that could lead someone to fail to understand the hardships and psycological damage caused by the hand that life dealt Peter!  he was a remarkable man far from home, persecuted for his country of origin, a widower left with 4 small children in the slums of London's East End.  He may have been German but in both WW's he tried to serve his country (England!) unfortunately the powers that be would not have it! although a true Brit he was stoned out of a Bakery in the East End in WW1 and a Pub in WW2, makes you wonder why he stayed so loyal? I believe his genes are what make his descendants so resilient! and by God we are!

Peter Gotz was my Great Grandfather I am proud to say so, My father was proud to have him as a Grandfather and my Grandfather, his son, was also proud of him!  Only the folly of youth could fail to understand the psycological damage caused by the hard life of being an immigrant in Londons East End at the turn of the 20th century.  A widower who's wife Annie died in childbirth, left with 4 young children, persecuted for his country of origin, who tried to serve his country (England) in both WW's and was rejected purely because of his nationality, stoned out of a Bakery in WW1 and Pub in WW2 it is amazing he remained loyal to his adopted country. I truely believe that it is his genes running through our veins that make my family so resilient.  We can be knocked down but we WILL NOT stay down! Thanks Peter x

Wikipedia says: Ernestine Schumann-Heink (15 June 1861 - 17 November 1936) was a well-known operatic contralto, noted for the great control, tone, beauty, and wide range of her singing. Link follows: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schumann-Heink
Thanks!  We'll add her first name to the source data and reload the description.

Two of Ernestine Schumann-Heink's children were daughters, Charlotte Heink was born ~1884 Marie Theresa Schumann was born ~1896 The boy looks compatible with her youngest son, born 12 Dec 1898 in New York. - www.findagrave.com/memorial/195890346/george_washington_s... The daughter here might be Marie Theresa (Mizzi). - www.findagrave.com/memorial/111173868/marie_therese_fox The older daughter, Charlotte can be seen with Marie in one of the photos at - www.findagrave.com/memorial/239680129/charlotte_greif To me, the daughter in this picture is a better match to Marie than Charlotte. Marie was first married in 1915. See www.newspapers.com/article/lancaster-new-era-marriage-of-... So this picture is probably no later than 1915. Aside 1: According to www.balboaparkhistory.net/glimpses/scheink.htm "In February 1906 she returned to Germany where she succeeded in getting six of her eight children out of the country. August, a merchant seaman, and Charlotte, the wife of Doctor Grief [Greif] in Leipzig, remained behind. According to German law, Schumann-Heink, by marrying a foreigner, had forfeited her property in Germany. Also, her boys were required to serve in the army before they could leave the country. The German courts decided the boys and daughter Marie could accompany her to America and that she could retain one-third of the money in Germany as she, rather than her deceased husband, had earned it. Her home in Germany was confiscated, and she had to buy it back." Aside 2: According to www.balboaparkhistory.net/glimpses/scheink.htm "While she was singing in the 1914 Bayreuth Festival, World War I began. She ordered her chauffeur to put an American flag in front of her automobile. The flag placated officials looking for enemy agents and enabled her to reach the American consul at Coburg. After a roundabout route which took her to Copenhagen, she, her son George Washington, her daughter Marie, and her accompanist, Mrs. Katherine Hoffman, finally sailed for America on a Holland-American liner out of Rotterdam."

The earliest mention I can find of Auto Polo is in New York Times articles dating from late 1912. One from December 3 tells of the first auto polo event held in New York, at Madison Square Garden the previous day. I can't find references to auto polo having been played anywhere in the United States outside the New York area. The Times Archives have several more articles on auto polo, published through the middle of 1913, and then there's no more mention of it. My guess is that people just came to their senses and went back to their ponies.
scary~

That's actually December 3, 1912, and it says auto polo came from the South and West.  

The article begins, "Not a few of the dwellers or toilers along Automobile Row have been predicting a popular future for auto polo, the game from the South and West which gave the public a number of thrills as a game and furnished food for thought for the motor enthusiast at Madison Square Garden in the week just ended."

Elizabeth Thomsen: Thanks for noting my typo. It is indeed supposed to be 1912, not 1913. But the article to which I linked does not begin with the paragraph you quoted. The article I linked begins "Auto polo made its debut to the New York public at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and last night, and everybody who saw the new game went away with nerves playing a new tune." The article makes no mention of the game having been played earlier the South and West. The article you quoted is from The Times of December 8, 1912. (Here's a link for those who would like to read the whole thing.) Thanks for digging it up. It wasn't among my original search results. Note to all: If links to The Times archive articles don't work, keep trying them. The site doesn't always cough stuff up the first time, which is probably why search engines don't find every article on a subject in a single search.

You can see something propping up the rear of the car on right.  It is a great gag shot and really demonstrates the inventiveness of jobbing photographers of the day.

good point, martin.

to my eye, it looks like there is an alteration to hide the same prop on the left car, too.
trey kazee: Yep, it looks like it got scratched out there below the wheel and behind it. To me it looks like the support went up to the axle. This is indeed a very cool setup.
great eye, Martin, it's hilarious they set these up. completely in the style of  the "jobbing photographers of the day", as you put it. What a find.
oh humanity, what have you done now?

Yes, the cars are completely static.  The wheel spokes are completely sharp, unheard of with the equipment of the day.  This is definitely staged, probably to recreate real "thrills and spills" you'd see if you came to the real thing.

The "drivers" are jumping.  Nice stunt work, if nothing else.

Alburt A. Shillcutt patented this machine in US Patent 1,043,473 on November 5, 1912. Shillcutt is given in the patent as a citizen of the United States, residing in Little Rock, Arkansas. In those times often models were made to give more truth to the patent. The drawings in the patent are remarkably similar to the model presented in the Baines picture. I think it is safe to date this picture as 1912. The machine and probably Shillcutt too are described in the early US aviation periodical Aeronautics: the American magazine of aerial locomotion year 1912, page 179. Interesting and unique picture probably, but there may be more of them in that Magazine Aeronautics. Cheers Kees

Rosalie Gardiner Jones (1883-1978) was a wealthy Oyster Bay socialite and suffragist known as "General Jones"--she also had a law degree, and late in life was infamous for keeping many goats on her estate. www.newsday.com/community/guide/lihistory/ny-past1215,0,6... Jessie Belle Hardy Stubbs MacKaye was originally from Chicago, and one-time president of the Milwaukee Women's Peace Society. She was Columbia University educated, and legislative chair of the Women's Peace Society in NYC. She was noted for "urging all women to remain unmarried or to refuse to bear children until some efficient means should be devised to secure the world against the devastation of war." Jessie Stubbs died by suicide in 1921. While grieving her death, husband Benton Mackaye began formulating the idea that became the Appalachian Trail. www.erikness.com/Stories/bentonmackaye.html

It appears to be a 10" coastal defense gun on a "disappearing" mounting, where the gun would fire from the raised (above a parapet) position, then the recoil would swing the gun back and down, where it would be invisible to the enemy.
Thanks!  We'll change the information in the source data and reload the description.

I'm not so sure it's a 10-inch gun now that I've seen this photograph: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2496403839 which has as the caption, "Aiming 14" gun -- Sandy Hook" Looks like a very similar gun to the one pictured here - and I think that the Sandy Hook emplacement would have been the closest to New York, and hence most newsworthy to the Bain service. However I'm not sure that Sandy Hook had a gun as big as a 14-incher. We'll have to do some more research.

Aha, you could be right. Also, 12' was a common size of gun on the disappearing mounts. In my print coastal defense references, there are many similar pics of 12" disappearing guns from the Endicott period. We need a real artillery geek to weigh in!

Bessie Pickens Abott (originally Abbott, her mother's maiden name; 1878-1919) was an American operetta singer, born Ogdensburg, NY, once part of a Vaudeville act with her twin sister Jessie.   Bessie was singing with Caruso in San Francisco's Grand Opera House when the 1906 earthquake happened.  She retired from performing after she married sculptor T. Waldo Story in 1912 (a bit of a scandal--his first wife, living in Rome, had long refused him a divorce, and claimed the marriage to Abott was illegal).   She was widowed in 1915.  Bessie Abott died in 1919, at the age of 40, "after an illness of several years."

Date inscribed on the negative (in reverse) appears to be from 1913, which would make this a few months after Woodrow Wilson assumed the Presidency on March 4, 1913. (View large.) 

William Gibbs McAdoo, Wilson's Secretary of the Treasury, was widowed in 1912. In 1913 he began courting Eleanor, Wilson's youngest daughter, who accepted his proposal, even though at 50 he was 27 years older than she. Woodrow Wilson was not thrilled by the idea, but did not prevent the marriage. McAdoo and Eleanor were divorced in 1934.

The Internet provides a few tantalizing hints to who Billy Wood may have been. He may have been the British wrestler William Wood, who won the silver medal in the lightweight (up to 66kgs) division of the freestyle wrestling competition at the 1908 Summer Olympics. Link: Wikipedia article on 1908 Olympic wrestling. Or maybe he was the Billy Wood who was Britain's middleweight wrestling champion in 1909 (middleweight being at least 76kgs, he'd have had to pack on quite a bit of weight in a year if William and Billy were the same guy.) Link: Google html cache of a big .pdf, with suitable highlighting. Or (and?) was he perhaps W. (Billy) Wood, styled "Welterweight Champion of the World" in a book about wrestling published by W. Foulsham & Co. of London sometime around the 1930s? The book, with text by E.J. Harrison, features posed photos of W. Wood and C. Law, illustrating wrestling holds. This book shows up for sale on the Internet in various editions. Link probably soon to die: A recent ebay UK offering of the book.

From: Maidremm@cs.com 
Subject: Pat Connolly 1917 World Class Wrestler 
Date: Fri, 5 Jul 2002 06:08:28 EDT 
Hello listers,

I am trying to find any and all information about Pat Connolly. He was born in Co. Galway Ireland, and wrestled in Butte, Montana. He was listed in articles as a British Citizen. He wrestled Ed "Strangler" Lewis on December 3, 1916, and on either January 13, or January 15, 1917 Pat Connolly and Yussif Hussane battled to a 2 1/2 hour draw in Butte, Montana. This 
information was taken from The Wrestling Datebook, 1915 thru 1920. Pat also wrestled Ed"Strangler" Lewis on November 30, 1916 in Billings, Montana.

On January 15, 1917, Pat Connolly had a niece born in Boston, MA, and she was to be Christened on January 28, 1917. Pat traveled by railroad to the Christening, and somewhere between Butte and Boston he died on the way. Some say he was poisoned, some say shot, etc. It still remains a mystery.

I am hoping that someone may know of this man, or heard this story. Any help would be very much appreciated.

Thank you one and all, Mary

In December 1911, William Thomas Wells fought Fred Storbeck at Covent Garden for the British Empire Heavyweight Title, scoring a knockout in the eleventh round to gain his second title in one year.

Fred Storbeck (1889-1970) was a South African heavyweight. Most of his career he fought in the U.K., in Australia, or in his native country. Here's his bout list page at boxer.com. The only American fight listed is his July 8, 1912 bout against Jim Stewart at Madison Square Garden (Storbeck lost.) My guess would be that this photo probably dates from that time.

This has to be a fairly early photo of Sweeney. Through most of his career he fought as a middleweight, usually at just over 160 lb. He was fighting as early as August 19, 1911, when he was 16 years old. Here's his bout list page at BoxRec. As is recorded there, by the middle of 1912 he was already over 130 lb., so this photo was most likelyly taken early that year or late in 1911. An excerpt from his obituary is quoted on this page. Both there and at BoxRec, the spelling of his real name is given as John Kraynack, rather than the "Kraynak" currently featured on his Wikipedia page. Odds are it's Wikipedia that's got it wrong.

Finding another of the Bain photos with push-pins, I found myself wondering when the push-pin was invented. The answer is that the patent was filed in 1899 and granted in 1900. See www.google.com/patents?id=pT5TAAAAEBAJ and www.push-pin.com/mpphist1.html Interestingly, the inventor's "first big deal was a sale of $1,000 worth of push pins to the Eastman Kodak Company." So they were for use by photographers. The patent emphasizes that they are of material that will not corrode in the presence of fluids used for developing negatives. I assume these have glass heads.

Precise date of birth in 1890 unknown. 
Considered a "White Hope" 
Shot by his father during an argument and killed. 
When Jack Johnson became the first African-American ("Negro") World Heavyweight Champion, in December 1908, many people clamored for the Heavyweight Title to return to a Caucasian ("White") fighter. After Johnson decisively beat James J. Jeffries--the former Champion who had retired undefeated but been lured back to fight Johnson-- on July 4, 1910, the term "White Hope" was coined. 

As the March 1930 The Ring magazine stated:
"It was back in the period between 1910 and 1915 that every overgrown small town lad who thought he had any ability, was signed by big and small time managers, placed in the hands of trainers, with the dethroning of Jack Johnson as the chief objective. From the most unheard of places there came prospective heavyweight champions. They loomed on the fistic horizon from far off sections which were scarcely visible to the naked eye. 

"Some came on and begged for a chance because they saw big money ahead. Others were sent along by big moneyed men who thrived on the publicity they were getting. Still others were grabbed up by good judges of fighters from the mines, the lumber camps and the farms. Most of them came quickly and hit the trail back home even quicker." 

Some of these White Hopes included: 

Carl Morris: considered the original "White Hope." His hopes were crushed by a loss to Fireman Jim Flynn. 
Luther McCarty 
Al Palzer 
Charley Miller, the "Fighting Motorman," whose chances were also quashed by a knockout loss to Fireman Jim Flynn. 
Jess Willard--who, in fact, eventually did win the Title from Johnson 
See also, The Great White Hopes: The Quest to Defeat Jack Johnson 

from "http://www.boxrec.com/media/index.php/White_Hope"
Great background info for this photo

This looks like the same location where the other photo of Al Palzer posted a few weeks ago was taken. Palzer was active in the ring in New York from 1911-1913, but the majority of articles about him in the New York Times archive are from 1911 and 1912, and the Bain Collection photos of him would most likely date from that period. It was after Palzer's defeat by Luther McCarty at Vernon, California, on New Year's Day, 1913, that McCarty was proclaimed "White Heavyweight Champion" of the world, the first time that title was awarded. Within weeks, Palzer's manager was promoting a match between Palzer and Jack Johnson, probably reasoning that, should Palzer defeat Johnson, the white fans would be so eager to recognize him as world champion that McCarty's ersatz title would be cast aside despite his New Year's Day victory. Though Johnson accepted the challenge, the bout never took place, and Palzer never won the heavyweight title. From The Times, January 18, 1913: JOHNSON AGREES TO BOX PALZER IN PARIS.

The 1930 title for this picture is probably misleading. Here is the argument: 1) The LoC text shown above also mentions the date of Aug 13, 1912. 2) Here is Washington team's schedule for 1912, from : www.baseball-reference.com/teams/WSH/1912_sched.shtml In 1912 WSH played played CHW 11 times at home and 11 times in Chicago, here are the dates: 1912 WSH Home games vs CHW (11 games): May 7,8,9, 10 July 13, 15, 16 Aug 13,14, 15, 16 1912 WSH Away games vs CHW (11 games) June 5,6,7,8 Aug 4, 5, 6, 7 Sept 20, 22nd (dbl header) So there was a WSH-CHW home game on the Aug 13, 1912 date, lending support to that date. 3) Taft died March 8, 1930 at age 72. He was ill and in and out of hospitals from January, 1930. On the other hand, he looks relatively hale and hearty in this photo. 4) Do the uniforms of the players and clothes of the fans look more like 1930 or 1912? 5) An article from NYTimes published August 13, 1912 (but dated Aug 12) reads: Taft will see Nationals Play To-day." President Taft, Major D. L. Rhoads, his personal aid; Gen. Clarence R. Edwards, and W.C. Herron, the President's brother in law, will occupy a box at American leage Park tomorrow, when the Washington team plays its first home game in several weeks and meets Chicago. The President believes Washington has a chance to win the pennant this year." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E04E4DB1630E233A... It would seem likely that the date is actually 1912 and not Feb, 1930. The 1912 date is interesting as this date is right in the midst of the political turmoil about the 3-way, or 4-way election of 1912, between Taft, T.R. Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson.

A search in chroniclingamerica.loc.gov will uncover mentions of Drobach winning, placing high, or participating in many races from 1908 through 1922 - a fairly long career. Road racing was not common - over this period the kind of bicycle racing that was popular varied somewhat over time and Drobach seems to have been able to do well in many types, including motor-paced cycle racing (drafting at high speed behind a motorcycle), relatively short distance races in velodromes, and six-day bicycle races in venues such as Madison Square Garden. This head-on photo doesn't allow much appreciation of the bicycle he was on, but it would have been a single speed track back, which is probably all he ever rode in competition. A bicycle such as that, with no gears or brakes, could be built at a low weight (no heavier than a present day road bike made of carbon fiber) but sufficiently strong. The rider could have the gearing changed to suit the type of race. Occasionally one can find a photograph like this in a newspaper in Chronicling America but I don't see this one.

His full name was John Adolphus Clark (Jr.), birthdate 1 March 1888 at Camperdown, Victoria, Australia, and he immigrated to the U.S. in April 1906 (per his 1920 passport application on Ancestry.com). In 1920 he was going to visit his parents in Australia, and his occupation was listed as "professional cyclist and hotel proprietor". John Adolphus Clark married Rena A. Bray on 31 Aug 1910 in Salt Lake City, UT but they were apparently divorced. Marriage license: udn.lib.utah.edu/cgi-bin/showfile.exe?CISOROOT=/tgm2&... Marriage record: abish.byui.edu/specialCollections/westernStates/westernSt... Don't know if he later had another marriage. Article at udn.lib.utah.edu/cgi-bin/showfile.exe?CISOROOT=/tgm2&...: Salt Lake Telegram (newspaper), 14 Mar 1915: NEWARK, March 13.--- "Jackie Clark, the Australian cyclist, will now have U.S.A. entered after his name on all programs. The little fellow from the land of the kangaroo was granted his naturalization papers last week in Newark. Clark's application was heard by Judge Martin in the common pleas court in the New Jersey city, and the judge at first denied the application when there was a slipup on the part of the cyclist in regards to the latter having lived in Salt Lake City during the season of 1911. After Jackie, who had pleaded to be a United States citizen under the name of JOHN ADOLPHUS CLARK, proved by contracts and letters bearing on that season the judge promptly accepted the documents as good proof and granted the papers." "Adolphus John Clark", birthdate 1 Mar 1888 in a foreign country, died 22 Dec 1958 in Santa Barbara County, California (per California Death Index on Ancestry.com)

See NYT article at query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0DE4DC1E3AE633A... MME. NAZIMOVA MARRIES.; Actress Weds Charles E. Bryant, Her Leading Man in "Bella Donna." December 6, 1912, Friday In the presence of only a few intimate friends, Mme. Alla Nazimova and her leading man, Charles E. Bryant, were wedded at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the apartments of the actress at 10 West Fortieth Street. The wedding was kept a secret, but the fact became known and the other members of the company playing in "Bella Donna" at the Empire Theatre showered congratulations upon the pair when they appeared at the evening performance. --- I imagine the photo is a promotional photo, presumably for 'Bella Donna' since the NYT piece indicates that he played a doctor.

There seems to be some doubt as to whether they were legally married. Some sources say they were divorced in 1925. For variations on her bio, see www.csse.monash.edu.au/~pringle/silent/ssotm/Feb99/ , en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alla_Nazimova , www.filmreference.com/Actors-and-Actresses-Mo-No/Nazimova... or www.imdb.com/name/nm0623417/bio See www.flickr.com/photos/pantufla/284177417/ and flickr.com/photos/pantufla/284178663/ for pictures of Nazimova as Salome (with Beardsley, or Beardsley-like, graphics). library: did the bain folks paint onto the glass negative, is the glass itself damaged or did a scanning error produce the strangely blown-out parts on this gentleman's face?

memos to the future:

Good question!  An inspection of the original glass negative reveals there is corrosion or similar damage (not silvering) in the negative emulsion on that region of the face, causing the emulsion to appear darker there, and therefore extra white in the scan.  So, it does appear the scan is a faithful reproduction of a slightly damaged glass negative.

Aha! See this page on Battleship Moreno. Clearly this is one of the Rivadavia class battleships, of which only two were built, the Moreno, or the Rivadavia, I presume. Quoting, briefly, from that site: Laid down on July 9, 1910, launched on June 28, 1911 and commissioned in December 1914, Moreno carried a main armament of twelve 12 inch main guns mounted two per turret. Two superfiring turrets were on the centerline both fore and aft and there was one wing turret per side that could fire both fore and aft and to both sides. Mrs. Helen Britton was "owner of the St. Louis National League Club"--see New York Times, December 10, 1912, p. 13.

Helen (or Helene) Hathaway Robison Britton (1879-1950) was from Cleveland; she inherited ownership of the St. Louis Cardinals (yes, the baseball team!) from her uncle, Stanley Robison, in 1911. So she's baseball history: bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&pid=16895&am... "It was her decision to lure women to games by introducing a Ladies Day, when all "fanettes" accompanied by male escorts were admitted to the grandstand free. She also hired a crooner to perform between innings. In an era when following baseball and attending games unescorted were considered unladylike, Helene abated society's misgivings while encouraging her own gender to develop an interest in the sport." She divorced Cardinals president Schuler Britton in 1917, sold the team in 1918 (after years of resisting offers), remarried, and died in Philadelphia at the age of 71.

Speaking at the suffrage meeting advertised on the flier seen here, Carrie Chapman Catt has a close connection to International Women's Day (IWD). In 1904, she was elected to the first board of the International Woman Suffrage Alliance at a meeting in Berlin and reelected in 1906 in Copenhagen. She promoted suffrage for women in her travels around the world in 1911-1912, stopping in South and East Africa, the Middle East, India, China, and many other places.
